This study presents atomistic simulations grounded in density functional theory (DFT) calculations that explore the dissociation of oxygen molecules on the Al(111) surface.

Calculations were conducted using the rapid adiabatic following method, which allows for the characterization of non-adiabatic dynamics by solving the time-dependent Schrödinger equation within a mixed normal-Wigner representation Hamiltonian framework.
The simulation method is initially validated by comparing it with experimental reaction coordinates for both the associative and dissociative pathways.
The findings are subsequently presented for the initial genuine non-adiabatic dynamics simulations of oxygen molecule dissociation on Al(111).
The study revealed that non-adiabatic effects can significantly influence both the associative and dissociative pathways, particularly by impacting the transition state ensemble.
The impact of the substrate on the dissociation process was ultimately examined.
These simulations provide the first detailed account of the non-adiabatic dissociation process of O2 molecules on the Al(111) surface.
The simulations indicate that the dissociative pathway is non-adiabatic, while the associative pathway remains adiabatic all the way to the transition state.
In the dissociative pathway, the non-adiabatic coupling is quite significant at the onset of the transition state, whereas it remains minimal in the associative pathway.
Ultimately, the simulations demonstrate that the substrate significantly influences the dissociation process.
The Al(111) surface features two stable configurations for the O2 molecule: 1x2 and 2x2.

The 1x2 configuration represents a linear geometry, where the oxygen atom is situated at the top and the two hydrogen atoms occupy the bridge position. In contrast, the 2x2 configuration corresponds to a bent geometry, with the oxygen atom placed in the second position.
The orientation of the molecular axis distinguishes these two structures.
In the subsequent discussion, we will refer to the 2x2 O2 structure as "bent" and the 1x2 O2 structure as "linear."
At first, the O2 molecule is situated on the surface in a linear configuration, occupying either a top or bridge position.
A sufficiently high energy excitation will result in the reorientation of the molecular axis into a 1x2 O2 configuration, with the molecular axis directed toward the substrate.
The nuclear wavepacket associated with this excitation exhibits a significant amplitude at the peak of the linear structure while nearly disappearing at the bridge position.
These simulations illustrate that the molecular axis is positioned above the bridge site on the Al surface, which aligns with experimental observations.
This excitation will also cause the O2 molecule to dissociate into two atomic oxygen atoms.
Nevertheless, only a small segment of the wavepacket concentrated on the linear structure is initially engaged in the dissociation process, which is consistent with the experimental data available.
This indicates that the associative pathway is adiabatic.
In this study, we take an additional step by examining the non-adiabatic dynamics associated with both pathways.
To achieve that goal
The Stokes equation seems to effectively characterize the long-wavelength (low-frequency) dynamics of liquids like water.
In this case, viscosity indicates a localized divergence in the velocity field.
The incompressibility of the liquid also suggests a divergence in the stress tensor.
The balance between stress and elastic forces generates an intrinsic shear wave, the amplitude of which diminishes with the inverse square of the distance from the point of force application.
These basic assumptions sufficiently explain the majority of complex non-equilibrium phenomena observed in the low-frequency rheology of Newtonian fluids.
In practice, it is important to note that most real-world liquids exhibit non-Newtonian characteristics.
This is especially noticeable at long wavelengths, where the elastic forces become insignificant in comparison to the viscous forces.
In this scenario, viscosity is the sole driving force.
It remains to be determined whether this straightforward model can effectively explain the low-frequency rheology of these fluids.
An observation using spectropolarimetry of the Ca II lines at 8498 Å and 8542 Å in the quiet Sun was presented.
The data were collected using the Dutch Open Telescope in conjunction with the new Waveslicer onboard the Meteor satellite.
The spectropolarimetric data cubes span a field of view measuring 30 by 30 solar radii, with a resolution of 0.33 by 0.33 arcseconds.
The observed region was located near the center of the solar disc and featured a granule with a resolution of 4 by 4 Mm.
Polarization signals were detected in both the line profiles and the continuum, but no circular polarization signals exceeding the detection threshold of 0.1 percent were found.
The line-of-sight component of the magnetic field strengths was calculated using the forward integration method and determined to be approximately 100 G.
The average field strength values at the center of the granules ranged from 50 to 200 G.
Recent cosmological simulations of galaxy evolution have successfully replicated both the morphology-density relationship and the star formation rate-density relationship found in nearby galaxies.
However, these simulations are unable to capture the complete range of galaxy properties across both low and high redshift.
It has been proposed that feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN) and quasars could influence the regulation of star formation within their host galaxies.

This paper showcases high-resolution cosmological hydrodynamical simulations focusing on a subset of galaxies within a single volume of a comprehensive modern simulation that incorporates a straightforward model for radio-mode feedback.

The model features a constant Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton accretion rate onto the supermassive black hole, calibrated to ensure that the active galactic nucleus (AGN) provides a predetermined level of radio heating to the interstellar medium.

We have chosen a volume-limited simulation that captures all galaxies above a specified mass and incorporates the effects of stellar feedback, AGN feedback, and the changing gas properties derived from the larger simulation.

Our findings indicate that, even in the absence of AGN-triggered starbursts, the momentum provided by radio mode feedback is sufficient to significantly disrupt the cold streams at the heart of cooled galaxy clusters, thereby inhibiting the formation of bright elliptical galaxies.
At the same time, this feedback is not enough to fully disrupt the clusters.

In lower mass galaxies, which are beneath the critical cluster mass, there is no notable suppression of star formation. However, we do observe a reduction in both stellar metallicity concentration and stellar density.

In conclusion, although radio-mode feedback plays a significant role in regulating star formation in the early universe, it cannot fully account for the entire distribution of galaxies observed in the Hubble sequence.
The analysis of homogeneous spaces through Fourier techniques has a rich historical background in the field of analysis.
The convolution of locally compact groups is a significant and extensively researched operation in mathematics.

In contrast, the development of Fourier analysis on semisimple Lie groups and their homogeneous spaces has been relatively limited, even though these concepts arise naturally within the representation theory of Lie groups.
In this paper, we derive convolution results for these groups by drawing parallels with the locally compact case.

This study is a continuation of a series where we investigate the structure and representation theory of semisimple Lie groups and their associated homogeneous spaces.

In this paper, we investigate how restricting a hard-sphere fluid between two parallel hard walls influences its average characteristics.
To begin with, we compute the perturbation correction to the equation of state for the ideal hard-sphere fluid.
This correction becomes increasingly insignificant when the density ratio between the wall and fluid is low, and the distance between the walls significantly exceeds the particle diameter.

By applying this perturbation result, we demonstrate that the variation in the average density of the fluid caused by confinement is proportional to the volume of the space bounded by the confining walls.
We will now investigate how confinement influences the structure factor, demonstrating that it also scales with the volume of the space.

It was observed that large spirals exhibited statistically significant regular magnetic fields.
These fields vary from a few gauss to several tens of milligauss and are structured in a poloidal manner, featuring nearly field-free areas at the periphery of the galaxy.

Massive young stellar objects (MYSOs) rank among the brightest and most dynamic entities in the interstellar medium. However, their intricate structures and the process through which they evolve into vibrant stellar clusters present significant challenges for researchers.
In this letter, we offer a high-frequency radio continuum investigation spanning multiple epochs, focusing on a sample of 38 massive young stellar objects (MYSOs).
These sources have been selected for their robust water maser activity, making them potential indicators of high-mass star formation.

We observe a significant occurrence of positive spectral index gradients, with around half of the sample showing this characteristic. These gradients are typically substantial and exhibit variability over timescales of weeks.
We understand this variability in free-free emission to be mainly generated by shocks produced by protostellar outflows and jets, which aligns with recent discoveries observed at lower frequencies.
We also observe a substantial population of sources exhibiting negative spectral index gradients, which are probably due to free-free emission from ionized accreting material.

The infrared luminosity, inferred mass accretion rates, and spectral gradient features of this sample indicate that a number of these sources could be undergoing a transition from massive young stellar objects (MYSOs) to either evolved stars with ionized inner disks or to less massive stars surrounded by circumstellar disks.
A droplet approaching and bouncing on a smooth horizontal surface might be perceived by an observer as having a consistent size.
What was the actual change in size?
The clear explanation is that it bounces together as a single unit, distributing its lift across the entire drop.
This straightforward model, referred to as the unit bounce, was introduced in the 17th century and continued to align with experimental results until the late 1800s.
Since that time, droplets impacting a solid surface at sufficiently high relative humidity (RH) exhibit irregular changes in size: some areas experience shrinkage while others see growth.
This phenomenon, referred to as non-uniform bouncing, was initially identified in 1908 and is now extensively recorded in videos.
This phenomenon is unexpected and may not align with the traditional bouncing model.
We introduce a straightforward model that forecasts the lifespan of a bouncing droplet, demonstrating that this lifespan is limited.
Following a brief qualitative overview of the model, we will provide a more comprehensive description that includes a partial differential equation, which is solved using numerical methods.
The solution accurately reflects the main characteristics of the observed non-uniform bouncing, including the regions that expand and contract, as well as their duration.
We subsequently explore a range of physical mechanisms that might account for the observed effects, addressing both the proposed model and the more conventional framework of droplet bouncing.

Recent advancements in treating dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) as a constrained variational approach have resulted in an effective numerical implementation within the linear muffin-tin approximation (LMTA).
We present the inaugural implementation that enables the computation of both fermionic self-energies and associated response functions.

In this implementation, the Hartree-Fock-like principle of avoiding double counting of interactions and response functions is achieved by integrating a simple partial derivation of the LMTA equations with a constraint on charge density.

By applying the LDA+DMFT approximation to the photoemission spectrum of the half-filled three-dimensional Bethe lattice, we demonstrate that this approach produces charge-density profiles that align closely with those obtained from the complete solution of the LDA+DMFT equations, all while significantly reducing computational expenses.

We present the inaugural implementation that facilitates the computation of both fermionic self-energies and associated response functions.

Recently, a method for implementing Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT) within the framework of the linear muffin-tin approximation (LMTA) has been suggested.

In this implementation, the Hartree-Fock-like principle of avoiding double counting of interactions and response functions is achieved by integrating a simple partial derivation of the LMTA equations with a constraint on the charge density.

In this study, we present the first calculation of dynamical response functions using the LMTA method. Our findings demonstrate that this approach produces charge-density profiles that closely match those obtained from a complete solution of the LDA+DMFT equations, while offering a significantly reduced computational cost.

In Dissipative Particle Dynamics (DPD), the interactions among various particles are represented by short-range, collision-based forces that are roughly mean-zero and exhibit a predefined auto-correlation function.
This method, which handles short-range interactions using Gaussian white noise, is effective for particle separations that are significantly greater than the dissipative length scale.
At shorter distances, the correlations between the force and its underlying velocity, which depend on the separation, result in the noise exhibiting non-Gaussian characteristics.

We obtain an effective stochastic interaction by analyzing the correlation between force and velocity across various separations and applying a least squares fitting method to establish a two-point covariance function.

This covariance function allows stochastic interactions at short distances to more accurately represent the non-Gaussian force correlations observed at intermediate separations, while still facilitating effective coupling at larger distances, where the noise begins to resemble Gaussian behavior.

The DPD equations of motion obtained are integrated using a stochastic velocity-Verlet method, and the reliability of the effective interaction is assessed by comparing it to simulations of thermal equilibrium behavior.
We provide numerical data on three-nucleon observables in nuclear matter as a function of the pion mass.

The predictions are derived within a coupled-cluster expansion of the nuclear wave function, employing two types of interaction kernels: a long-range kernel that reflects the leading order of a systematic chiral perturbation theory (ChPT) expansion, and a short-range kernel that accounts for two-nucleon contact interactions.

We demonstrate that, for observables associated with nuclear matter saturation, the convergence of results to the physical point is influenced by the interaction range, exhibiting quicker convergence when utilizing a short-range kernel.

Furthermore, for a specific range of interaction, the influence of the pion mass on the predictions becomes more significant as the system's density decreases, which corresponds to an increase in the interaction range.

In conclusion, we contend that a suitable renormalization group analysis of Chiral Perturbation Theory (ChPT) is necessary to accurately characterize the evolution of the nuclear many-body system at the QCD scale.
By utilizing data from the Fermi Gamma Ray Space Telescope, we have identified gamma rays emanating from 37 supernova remnants (SNRs).
The gamma-rays are primarily generated by hadrons, with a lesser contribution from bremsstrahlung.
The observed gamma-ray spectra are accurately represented by a single power-law in kinetic energy, with indices ranging from 2.0 to 2.7.

The gamma-ray efficiency, defined as the portion of energy from a supernova explosion that is emitted as gamma-rays, is approximately 1% for young supernova remnants (SNRs). This efficiency rises as the SNR ages, corresponding to an increase in the amount of shocked gas present.

The production rates of hadronic gamma rays are only a few percent of the historical outputs, indicating that cosmic-ray particles travel through a dense medium where their interactions are relatively gentle.

We conclude that the detected gamma-rays align with expectations from interactions of nuclei with background protons; however, the considerable uncertainties in the local cosmic-ray density and composition leave room for substantial contributions from electrons and Dark Matter particles.

The observation of gamma-rays from young and middle-aged supernova remnants (SNRs) that lack corresponding radio synchrotron emissions poses a challenge to current models explaining gamma-ray production in SNRs.
Utilizing the Mileura Widefield Array low frequency demonstrator field prototype system, we present our findings on the observations of the crab giant pulses (GCTs).
The Mileura field is situated approximately 1260 km away from the moon's center and displays significant Faraday rotation.
In 2016, we conducted 20 hours of observations, during which we identified 5 GCTs and calculated Faraday rotation measures (RM) after each pulse.
We simultaneously activated 1.2 MHz of recording modes at two neighboring north-south locations within the array.
In this band, we identified two GCTs; however, their accuracy was limited to sub-meter precision because of the array's extensive field of view.
We calculate the distance between the GCTs using the dispersion measure (DM) and the rotation measure (RM), and we limit their sizes to approximately 1 milliarcsecond.
We observe DM and RM vectors generally aligned with the center of the GCT peaks, which aligns with the intense magneto-ionic conditions present in the magnetosphere of the Crab pulsar.

The results shown here indicate that the Mileura Widefield Array possesses the sensitivity needed to detect Galactic Cosmic Rays (GCTs) with dispersion measures (DMs) of up to approximately 15 pc/cm³. Additionally, it demonstrates the capability to conduct multi-frequency searches for variations in DM and rotation measure (RM) across GCT pulses.
These observations may be capable of identifying the Earth's rotation in relation to the magnetosphere of a rotating neutron star.
This paper aims to present a methodology that utilizes Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Automatic Relevance Determination (ARD) to facilitate swift data acquisition in geoscience applications.

The proposed method was applied in hydrogeological contexts, utilizing data obtained from Ground-Penetrating Radar (GPR) signals collected in the same area where pressure variations are to be assessed.
The suggested approach involves two stages.
Initially, various signals were captured under different conditions, and from this collection, a selection of data will be chosen for the learning process.
The selection criteria rely on the prediction error derived from a model that follows a Kalman Filter (KF) framework, utilizing the recorded data to forecast pressure fluctuations.
Next, Principal Component Analysis is performed on the chosen data to reduce its dimensionality and develop a more efficient model.
The proposed methodology has been evaluated using synthetic data and benchmarked against the ARD technique, demonstrating the effectiveness of the suggested approach.
We announce the observation of six magnetically-driven explosions from rapidly-rotating white dwarfs (WDs) that occurred after the collapse induced by accretion.
The survey utilizes the ASAS-SN virtual telescope, which observes the entire visible sky every few hours.
These objects had not previously displayed such explosions, as all known examples before were associated with low-mass white dwarfs.
These explosions exhibit a swift increase in brightness in the days prior to the event, which is then followed by a plateau before eventually fading in magnitude.
The plateau results from the continuous collapse of the rotating white dwarf into either a neutron star or a black hole.
The presence of an underlying plateau in the subsequent light curve confirmed the explosion, a feature that is absent in instances of stable nuclear burning on the surface of the white dwarf.
The duration of the plateau and its luminosity align with the anticipated range for the amount of material that has been ejected.

We analyze the observations in relation to one-dimensional hydrodynamical simulations of accretion-induced collapse, both with and without the incorporation of strong magnetic fields. Our results indicate that the simulations that account for magnetic fields most effectively replicate the emission.

We estimate that the magnetic fields needed to induce the explosions are around 100 megagauss, a level that exceeds the capabilities of upcoming magnetore facilities, including the Exawatt Center for Plasma Research in the EU and NASA's Long Duration Balloon Program.
We present findings on the identification of six exploding white dwarfs, each of which had been previously observed by ASAS-SN.

Out of the six, four exhibited plateau-like light curves featuring notable declines in brightness in the days preceding the explosion, which aligns with earlier observations of magnetically-driven explosions from low-mass white dwarfs.

Two other objects, SDSS J0804+2052 and SDSS J2315+1855, exhibited noticeable plateau-like drops in magnitude following their earlier brightness increases. This observation aligns with the theory of magnetically-driven explosions originating from rapidly-rotating white dwarfs, marking a significant confirmation of this scenario for the first time.

We analyzed the observed plateau durations and luminosities, comparing them with simulations both with and without magnetic fields. Our findings indicate that the emission was most accurately matched by the simulations that incorporated magnetic fields.

By analyzing the plateau durations and luminosities we recorded, we determined the ejected material masses for each event. Our findings indicated that these masses fell within the anticipated range for materials released during such explosions.

We identified the likely locations of the progenitor stars by cross-referencing our sample with Gaia Data Release 2. Our findings suggest that four of the exploding white dwarfs are most likely situated within the field of view of their corresponding host galaxies.
This aligns with the notion that explosions from rapidly rotating white dwarfs are more likely to be observed from their host galaxies compared to explosions from low-mass white dwarfs.

Our research indicates that magnetic fields play a crucial role in the mechanisms and results of explosions in this astrophysical context, suggesting that these explosions could effectively help retain mass in rapidly rotating white dwarfs.
We announce the identification of six exploding white objects.
Francium (Fr), radon (Ra), noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, Kr, and Xe), and halogen atoms (F, Cl, Br, and I) form isoelectronic sequences.

In this study, we showcase electronic structure calculations aimed at predicting the electron affinity (EA), excitation energies (EX), excitation spectra, polarizabilities (PA), and lifetime (τ) for the francium isoelectronic series.
We estimate the electron affinity (EA) of FrH- to be 4.15 ± 0.04 eV and the excitation energy (EX) to be 0.73 ± 0.15 eV.
The ionization potential (IP) of the Fr+ ion in the 0_00-1_00 SO2+ state is measured to be IP = 9.23 (3) eV.

The ionization potential for the 0_11-1_11 state is measured at 7.44 (3) eV. Additionally, the anticipated IP-IP separation of 1.33 (9) eV between the 0_00 and 1_00 states aligns remarkably well with experimental results.
The polarizability of Fr+ is measured at 155 (16) Å³, which aligns closely with the experimental value of 160 (15) Å³.
The 0_00-1_00 τ value in Fr+ is 1.48 (16) picoseconds.
This aligns well with the experimentally measured value of 1.59 (2) ps.
WZ Sge was initially recognized as a binary star system with strong interactions, featuring a K-type donor star and a white dwarf companion.
Utilizing the latest data, WZ Sge remains a remarkable example of a dwarf nova characterized by its exceptionally rapid outbursts.
The ASAS-SN recently detected the 2017 outburst.
WZ Sge holds the record for the longest recognized outburst interval among dwarf novae.
In this report, we present the findings from our extensive photometric and spectroscopic monitoring of WZ Sge, which has been ongoing since 2010.

In the 2D Ising model, when there is strong square coupling and the aspect ratio of the system approaches zero, a continuous phase transition occurs at temperature Tc. In the low temperature phase, the interfaces are pinned by Gaussian disorder, while in the high temperature phase, these interfaces become unpinned.
Through Monte Carlo simulations, we estimate the critical exponent related to the order of the transition to be \( o = 1.23(2) \).
We present an effective dynamic renormalization group (DRG) approximation to address the problem.
The DRG flows for the effective interface tension and Gaussian disorder strength were found to be incompatible with the two-sided free field fixed point.
This suggests that the transition is, in fact, continuous.
The estimated critical exponents are \( o = 1.25 \pm 0.05 \).
We compared our DRG results with the strong coupling expansion from reference [1], and we observed an outstanding quantitative agreement for temperatures below Tc.
Beyond Tc, the dynamics of our DRG flows do not converge, necessitating the search for a new fixed point that possesses nontrivial field content.

In quantum mechanics, the density operator is a Hermitian operator that assigns a projection value, representing the state of a quantum system characterized by uncertainty.
The density operator is a crucial mathematical construct in quantum mechanics that represents the statistical information of a quantum system.
In this paper, we explore the geometry of the set of density operators within a complex Hilbert space, which constitutes the quantum state space.
To begin with, we introduce a generalized version of von Neumann entropy and describe the entropy landscape across the entire set of quantum states.
We subsequently examine the extreme points and the convolution structure, and offer different characterizations of the set of quantum states that are physically permissible.
We will demonstrate that a quantum state qualifies as a density state if and only if it can be represented as a tomographic probability distribution.
Using these results, we develop a cohesive geometric framework for constructing positive maps, which allows us to fully classify super-operator positive maps on trace-class operators.
For instance, we offer a specific formula for the operator Jordan map, which can be viewed as a quantum counterpart to the complex equator of the Riemann sphere.
The asymptotic behavior of eigenfunctions in the semiclassical limit is investigated for a family of operators associated with the one-dimensional Schrödinger operator that has a periodic potential.

By applying the classical shooting method, it is demonstrated that the spectral problem corresponds to a new set of operators whose parameter is influenced by the derivative of the periodic potential.
The new operators were established within a "homogenized" domain, where it is assumed that the spectrum is consistently distinct from the essential spectrum.
In the semiclassical limit, the family of operators transforms into a Schrödinger operator characterized by constant coefficients.
The asymptotic behavior of the eigenfunctions was analyzed with reference to Floquet theory, where the fixed dispersion relation was substituted with a uniform separation of the spectrum.
It was demonstrated that the eigenfunctions are both real-valued and take the form of trigonometric polynomials.
The semiclassical quantization condition for the potential's period is derived and demonstrated to be equivalent to Gutzwiller's trace formula.
Proposed realizable Hamiltonians are designed for universal adiabatic quantum computing.
Unlike previous proposals, our Hamiltonians can be realized using currently available quantum devices.
We examine a general framework for achieving a target unitary and an adiabatic evolution over a time duration T.

The generated Hamiltonian can include any term that is supported by the eigenstates of the initial Hamiltonian. Consequently, it cannot generally be represented as a sum of bilinear terms of the form {|,i}H{i,}{,}.
We introduce a comprehensive framework for determining the realizability of the final Hamiltonian in relation to a specified target unitary, provided that specific regularity conditions are met.

In a particular scenario where the final Hamiltonian is also expressed as a sum of bilinear terms of the specified form, we demonstrate that the implementation can be achieved using gadgets made up of qubit transverters and clusters of surface gates.
In a broader context, we present direct constructions that draw on Kitaev's quantum double model and its adaptation for surface codes.
We evaluate the performance of the resulting Hamiltonians using a Taylor series expansion.
Specifically, we demonstrate that the gap in the resultant Hamiltonian diminishes at the rate of 1/T², indicating that it closes exponentially at the optimal rate of T⁻².
This observation suggests that, for a universal T, the associated quantum computer needs an infinite amount of quantum seed state in its initial Hamiltonian to offset the accumulation of errors.
In conclusion, we explore potential strategies for addressing error accumulation and enhancing the performance of the resulting adiabatic quantum computers.
Fossil groups are substantial clusters of galaxies that are held together by the gravitational pull of a dominant central halo.
The galaxies within the groups are early-type, much like the central galaxy, which is characterized as having a cuspy structure.
We analyze the dynamics within galaxy groups and draw comparisons with a selected portion of the Millennium Simulation.
While the average group masses in the simulation align with observational data, the proportion of groups containing multiple luminous members is lower than what is seen in observed groups.

We examine the underlying factors and determine that the low multi-occupancy of the groups in the Millennium Simulation can be replicated using conventional models of galaxy-galaxy interactions and mergers, without requiring any alterations to the mass or dynamics of the groups.
The Millennium Simulation is an $N$-body simulation of the universe conducted by the Virgo Consortium, with funding from the American Astronomical Society.
The simulation's resolution is roughly 108 times greater than that of the Las Campanas survey.
I analyze the dynamics of galaxy groups in the Millennium Simulation and compare them to those observed in the Las Campanas survey.
The simulation shows a lower percentage of groups with several luminous members compared to the survey.

I examine the underlying reasons and find that the low multi-occupancy of the groups in the simulation can be replicated using conventional methods for modeling galaxy-galaxy interactions and mergers, eliminating the necessity for any changes to the mass or dynamics of the groups.
I verify this by examining the dynamics of groups in the Millennium Simulation alongside those observed in the Las Campanas survey.
Throughout the simulation, the average masses of the groups align with the observational data.
However, the proportion of groups containing multiple luminous members is lower than what was observed in the survey.

I explore the underlying factors and determine that the low multi-occupancy of the groups in the simulation can be replicated through standard approaches to galaxy-galaxy interactions and mergers, eliminating the necessity to alter the mass or dynamics of the groups.
Albert Einstein's formulation of general relativity is a fundamental pillar of contemporary physics.
It defines gravity as the distortion of space and time that occurs due to the uneven bending of these dimensions created by matter and energy.
General relativity is one of the most rigorously tested theories in physics, consistently demonstrating its reliability by successfully passing all experimental evaluations with impressive precision.
Nonetheless, some speculate that gaining a more profound understanding of gravity might necessitate the incorporation of new concepts and ideas.
In line with this trend, there has been a growing interest in the way we characterize gravitational interactions through Einstein's theory, particularly focusing on the process of renormalization.
Renormalization is the process used to remove the infinite values that arise within the theory by redefining its parameters.
As a result, a broader framework for gravitational theory was developed, encompassing a range of alternative theories, including f(R) gravity.
In this paper, we analyze this framework for renormalization.
We offer a comprehensive overview of the process, along with a detailed step-by-step guide for carrying out calculations within this framework.
We demonstrate this process through various examples, one of which involves computing the effective action for a system of gravitons.
We conclude with an analysis of our results and recommendations for future research.

The MINOS Experiment at FNAL has launched the first long-baseline neutrino oscillation appearance experiment utilizing the NuMI beamline and has recently released its results from the first year of operation.

The experiment employs a three-detector arrangement, featuring one detector positioned upstream at the Northern Initial Data taking site, alongside two downstream detectors located at the Soudan Underground Mine in Minnesota (NE detector) and in Saints, Louisiana (SW detector).
The data collection phase occurred between 2011 and 2012, during which the far detector recorded a total exposure of 2.2 ton-years.

Throughout this timeframe, MINOS recorded a muon neutrino disappearance with a significance level of 5.2σ, and also provided the first indication of electron neutrino appearance, achieving a significance of 3.6σ.
The initial results paper from MINOS showcases the latest data along with preliminary findings from the global fit analysis.
MINOS was designed to investigate the disappearance of muon neutrinos and the appearance of electron neutrinos produced by pions.

The updated dataset encompasses neutrino interactions with the detector from 2011 and 2012, and the global fit utilizes the complete dataset. This paper presents preliminary results that have been revised to reflect the inclusion of the full dataset.
The key update in the new results is the adjustment of event rates based on the enhanced cross section calculations provided by the NNPDF collaboration.
This enables a more accurate assessment of the experiment's background and sensitivity.
The experiment shows no signs of muon neutrino disappearance and provides 3.6σ evidence for the appearance of electron neutrinos.
The outcome carries some uncertainty due to our understanding of the neutrino flux and cross sections, which have been adjusted with this update.
Dewetting is a crucial micro-machining method used to fabricate nanometer-scale features across various materials, such as metals, semiconductors, and dielectrics.
The procedure involves stripping away a fine layer of material from one substrate to create a thin film on a different substrate.
Dewetting starts by selectively lowering the temperature in specific areas of the substrate material, which can be achieved through thermal, chemical, or mechanical patterning techniques.
A common dewetting scenario involves extracting a thin layer of material from a bulk semiconductor, resulting in the formation of a thin film on a different substrate.
This typically leads to the creation of one or more cavities that may have sharp edges and exhibit a high-energy surface due to the presence of a free air interface.
A major issue in this situation is the edge of the hole's capacity to return to equilibrium, which necessitates providing enough edge energy to counteract surface tension forces.

In this study, we conduct a comprehensive hydrodynamic analysis of the relaxation process of an initially circular dewetting hole, which is restricted at its edges while being able to move freely in two dimensions.

We analyze the changes in hole shape and energy in relation to both circular and elliptical equilibrium solutions, while also investigating the significance of different physical mechanisms involved in relaxation, such as bulk diffusion, convection, and surface tension.
In recent years, the concept of emergent spacetime has been proposed as a way to merge gravity with other fundamental forces, particularly quantum mechanics.

These emerging spacetimes have been demonstrated to develop in a bottom-up manner from coherent theories in a higher-dimensional framework, specifically general relativity in d dimensions combined with a scalar field.

In this paper, we demonstrate that when a specific coupling is selected between the scalar and gravitational fields, the resulting higher-dimensional spacetime exhibits an enhanced symmetry. This theory then manifests in an additional dimension, functioning as a dual gravitational theory characterized by a doubled number of spacetime dimensions.
In particular, we focus on the theory of a scalar field that exhibits a non-linear self-interaction within (d+1)-dimensional Minkowski space.
The equations governing motion feature a crucial point that relates to empty spacetime.

We demonstrate that by adding a new scalar field that is conformally coupled to the original one, the system acquires a greater symmetry and simplifies to a theory in d dimensions, featuring an emergent ((d-1)+1) dimensional Minkowski spacetime.
This theory permits the existence of non-trivial solutions that characterize black holes featuring multiple horizons, with a length scale determined by the black holes' charge.

Moreover, in the classical solution, there exists a smooth lower-dimensional region situated behind the black hole horizon. In this region, the original (d+1)-dimensional spacetime is seamlessly extended, with this extension represented by the configuration of a solitonic string that links the black hole horizon to the smooth region.

We investigate the solutions involving a single black hole alongside a cosmological horizon. Our findings indicate that when the charge is sufficiently large, the black hole horizon and the cosmological horizon merge, resulting in a tri-horizon solution.

We calculate the entropy of the black holes in the corresponding gravitational theory and discover that it aligns with the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of the black holes present in the tri-horizon solution.
Ultimately, we examine whether the general solution of the theory encompasses Reissner-Nordström black holes in higher dimensions, where the gravitational theory simplifies to five dimensions.
We conclude with an analysis of the findings and potential avenues for further exploration.

Watrous [19] provided a formal definition of quantum zero-knowledge proof (QKZP).
This definition employs two interactive probabilistic protocols.
Initially, the witness generation process simulates a specific probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) algorithm.
The second component, the simulator, can accommodate any probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) procedure as an adversary.
A verifier selects a random witness, forwards it to the simulator, and then receives a response.
The response should include a statement that outlines a polynomial-time verification condition for the initial procedure.

The proof is considered valid if the simulator accepts the witness with a probability of at least 2/3, while the witness generation phase is able to simulate the process with an advantage of at least 1/3.
In this study, we explore the fundamental characteristics of QKZP.
To begin with, we demonstrate that the definition can be articulated using the language of complexity theory.
By leveraging this information, we establish that the PSPACE assumption is essential to the definition.
We subsequently demonstrate that, with only black-box access to the original procedure, it is impossible to create a valid QKZP that achieves an advantage greater than 2/3.
These findings suggest that QKZP is trivial.
We introduce a variant of QKZP that boasts an improved soundness property.
The demonstration of the enhanced soundness is both intriguing and presents its own set of challenges.

A neutron star is a celestial object composed almost entirely of neutrons, which are subatomic particles associated with the atomic number of individual nuclei.
Neutron stars are astonishingly dense, containing more mass than the Sun compressed into a space roughly the size of a cubic kilometer or larger.
Neutron stars are created following a supernova explosion, which happens when nearly 99% of a star's mass is compressed into its core.
These extreme densities were attained because neutrons possess significantly higher density than regular atoms, and the strong force that holds nuclei together diminishes as one approaches the core.
When the core accumulates about 2-3 solar masses, it lacks sufficient mass to counteract the force of its own gravity.
The surplus energy was emitted in the form of a supernova explosion, which is also referred to as the formation of a neutron star.
The majority of neutron stars are located in close binary systems alongside another neutron star or, less frequently, a black hole.
These systems came to be referred to as low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs).
LMXBs present a fascinating opportunity for research, as they enable the examination of neutron stars from two distinct viewpoints.
The first state is referred to as "quiescent" (also called "inactive" or "non-pulsing"), in which the neutron star orbits a more compact companion without producing X-rays.
The second event occurs when the neutron star temporarily amplifies its X-ray emissions, a phenomenon known as an "outburst."
When an LMXB shifts from one state to another, examining the differences between these states becomes intriguing.
For instance, we have recently demonstrated that transiently brighter outbursts are linked to an increase in the neutron star's spin period.
On the other hand, when the neutron star is in a quiet state but its X-ray emission is slightly brighter than usual, its spin period tends to be longer compared to when the source is much dimmer.
These variations in behavior have led to the proposal of a "two-states" model to explain the behavior of LMXBs.

This model proposes two distinct accretion regimes for the neutron star, where the variations arise from different methods of how the captured material is transferred to the surface of the neutron star.
The first scenario, known as "Spoon-fed," describes how capture material, primarily protons, adheres to the surface of the neutron star, creating a distinctive spoon-shaped formation.
These transients were observed to be more luminous when the neutron star spins at a higher rate.
The second type is "Indirect," where the capture material, primarily composed of electrons and protons, creates a "cloud" surrounding the neutron star.
These transients appeared to be more luminous when the neutron star was observed in a particular state.

Blanco 1, located towards the Chamaeleon star-forming region at a distance of 120-150 parsecs, is recognized by Béjar et al. (2004) as a young open cluster, estimated to be approximately 10 to 30 million years old.
The masses of its low-mass members have not been directly assessed.
In this study, we estimate the masses of substellar members with masses around 10^-3 Mjup by combining adaptive optics imaging in the infrared with high-precision radial velocity measurements.
We obtain a lower mass function represented by n(m) ~ m^ - 1.5, with a median mass of 0.088 Mjup, which corresponds to 7% of the total cluster mass.
This represents the most in-depth investigation of the substellar realm within a young cluster to date.
The Blanco 1 cluster is comprised of low-mass members ranging from 30 Mjup down to the substellar domain, with a median mass of 0.088 Mjup.

In March 2017, the MiniBooNE experiment at Fermilab released new data that placed constraints on the potential number of sterile neutrinos that could mix with ordinary neutrinos.
These findings are derived from data collected between 2008 and 2011.

The recent data reinforced the hypothesis that there are at least two sterile neutrinos with a squared mass difference ranging from 0.15 to 2.29 eV², as well as at least one sterile neutrino possessing a non-zero mass.

Various neutrino mass models have been evaluated, but there is no indication that flavon fields are causing the masses to reach significantly large values, which would be anticipated in foundational theories like the See-Saw mechanism.
The oscillation parameters identified in this analysis align with the recent findings from the Daya Bay and RENO experiments.
This paper offers a critical assessment of recent findings from the MiniBooNE experiment and other studies, considering the implications of potential sterile neutrino types.
We present an overview of three prevalent hypotheses regarding the permissible masses and mixing of sterile neutrinos: the minimal scheme, the mixed scheme, and the two-zero scheme.
We introduce the formalism for each hypothesis and demonstrate the corresponding ranges of oscillation parameters for three illustrative sets of light neutrino mass splittings.
We explore various models for the generation of sterile neutrinos, which indicate different behaviors across the three mass schemes of sterile neutrinos.
In conclusion, we summarize the implications of recent findings on sterile neutrinos in the context of potential theoretical frameworks.
Authors: M. Maltoni and colleagues.

The concepts of weighted complexity and determinant functions for graphs are introduced.
These two new graph invariants extend several existing ones, including vertex cover, edge cover, matching, determinant, branching number, independence number, and total graph domination number.
Weights were allocated to the vertices based on their significance, with higher-weighted vertices being favored.

We demonstrate that the weighted complexity of a graph corresponds to the matching complexity of its line graph, and that the determinant of a graph is equivalent to the branch-width of its line graph.
We present various connections among these invariants.
Specifically, we demonstrate that both the weighted complexity and the determinant serve as lower bounds for matching complexity, branching number, and independence number.
Conversely, we present two graphs that have different weights, where the weighted complexity and the determinant remain identical, yet their matching complexity and branch-width differ.
In conclusion, we note that the challenge of calculating the weighted complexity and the determinant remains NP-complete, even when all the weights are set to one.
The interaction between proteins is essential for their stability and functionality.
Networks serve as an important tool for comprehending the connections between proteins and the way these interactions influence protein function.

The clustering coefficient quantifies how closely a node is connected within a local network of interrelated clusters. It has proven to be a crucial characteristic of complex networks, playing significant roles in areas such as network robustness, dynamics, and heterogeneity.
In this study, we calculated the clustering coefficients for several protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks.
The results indicate that the clustering coefficients of PPI networks are typically lower than those of their corresponding random networks.
Additionally, we have noted that the degree distribution of protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks adheres to a power law, which could account for the networks' low clustering coefficients.
Our results will enhance the understanding of the structure of PPI networks and their associated biological implications.
Zhang, W., Chen, M., Zhang, L., and Wang, J. (2017).
Clustering Coefficients in Networks of Protein-Protein Interactions.
arXiv preprint number arXiv:1705.04288.

HD 73526 is a spectroscopic binary system made up of two stars of similar mass that orbit around their common center of mass with a period of about 20.87 days.
This brief duration allows the two stars to interact significantly with one another by exchanging angular momentum, which eventually leads to the formation of a shared envelope.
This process is anticipated to significantly alter the arrangements of the stars and the characteristics of their orbits.

In this study, we conduct a comprehensive numerical integration of the relevant equations of motion to analyze the current configurations and orbital parameters of the system, along with their temporal variations.

After an initial phase in which the system dissipates a significant amount of orbital energy and angular momentum, it transitions into a state of resonant lock, where the period of the inner orbit matches that of the outer orbit.
The two stars are then seen to be in a stable arrangement, maintaining a consistent period, mass, and distance between them.
Large extra dimensions (LEDs) offer a natural mechanism for localizing conservation laws on a four-dimensional brane that exists within a higher-dimensional spacetime.
The LEDs need to be compact to address the hierarchy problem.

The perceived breach of energy conservation in our universe, suggested by the observed decrease in the cosmic microwave background (CMB), can be clarified through the theory that our universe originated on a brane situated within an anti-de Sitter (AdS) large extra dimension (LED) that has a negative cosmological constant.
In this situation, the universe seems to have four dimensions because of a fundamental clash between the conservation of energy in our brane world and the ongoing emergence of AdSLEDs.

In conventional cosmological models, the temperature of the observed Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) is the result of photons that were produced after the free electrons, which constitute the CMB, decoupled.
The photons journey through the observable universe before arriving at us.
As a result, the measured temperature of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) reflects the cumulative energies of all particles generated before they had the chance to interact with one another.
If the universe is purely four-dimensional without any extra space-time dimensions, then the conservation of energy is upheld, since all energy stays within the universe.
Nonetheless, if our universe is situated within an AdSLED that has a negative cosmological constant, this conservation is disrupted, since AdSLEDs arise from the dynamics of the brane world.
Tidal fields derived from the distribution of dark matter hold significant insights into the growth and merging history of galaxies, in addition to their current dynamics.

We provide both strong and weak lensing mass reconstructions of the Corullo-IATA1638+29 cluster, demonstrating that the two linked structures form a triple merger. The tidal field associated with the central galaxy highlights the cluster's orbital plane and its projected separation.

We also demonstrate that the orientations of the projected spins of the galaxies tend to cluster around this same plane. To quantify this alignment, we employ a two-dimensional Kuiper test to assess the significance of the spatial correlation with the orientation of the cluster’s tidal field.
We also examine the hypothesis that the spins of the galaxies were distributed uniformly, discovering a probability of less than 10^-4 that the orientation of these spins is random.
We conclude that the galaxies within this structure have oriented their spins in accordance with the orbital plane of their merger.
The three-dimensional space was densely populated with a tangle of three-dimensional curves.
All of these can be categorized based on their topological type, their algebraic type, or a combination of both.
The most captivating three-dimensional curves are the singular ones, which are typically n-dimensional and intersect transversally within n-dimensional space.
Singular curves have traditionally been categorized based on their genera, which refers to their codimensions within the parameter space.
In the late 1980s and early 1990s, a thorough theory of singular curves was established, particularly highlighted by the contributions of Harris, as well as the perspectives of Coppo and Garrone.
These studies establish a deformation theoretic framework to comprehend the birational classification of these curves, specifically their capacity to be infinitesimally transformed into one another.

This framework suggests that for a typical selection of a curve, there exists a plane within the nine-dimensional projective space of quadric hypersurfaces that does not intersect with the curve; this particular plane is referred to as an exceptional plane.
Curves that possess remarkable planes are referred to as decomposable.
This paper examines the scenario in which the generic curve is non-decomposable, specifically focusing on its possessing a unique exceptional plane that is unique up to projective equivalence.
These curves are referred to as non-decomposable.
The typical scenario occurs when the exceptional plane represents a plane of linear dependency for the general curve; this type of plane is referred to as an exceptional secant plane.

This paper advances the theory of such curves and presents various findings, including a birational classification known as the Wahl map. Additionally, it explains how the variety of non-decomposable curves of a specific genus—an open variety of infinite type—fibers over the space of curves characterized by a particular exceptional secant plane, which is of finite type.

Post-CCSD(T) molecular atomization energies—calculated with corrections for single and double excitations, but prior to frozen pair contributions—are usually determined using a smaller basis set compared to coupled cluster doubles (CCD) energies, even though there isn’t a strict justification for this practice.

In this study, we show that the convergence of basis sets for atomization energies can be explained using the pair natural orbital partial correction (PNOC), which effectively accounts for the significance of dynamic correlation in the post-CCSD energy calculations.
By employing explicit correlation as a measure, we demonstrate that PNOC energies converge to a greater extent than CCD energies as the size of the basis set increases.

This explanation enables us to anticipate that atomization energies calculated using the CBS-QB3 method—which integrates dynamic correlation via the CBS connection cost along with an adequately precise semi-local exchange-correlation functional—will converge significantly more quickly than CCSD(T) atomization energies when using a basis set that aligns with the quality of the CBS-QB3 geometry.

We examine this hypothesis across ten systems using experimental atomization energies and CCSD(T) geometries. Our results indicate that CBS-QB3 atomization energies converge within 1 kcal/mol when using a 6-31G** basis. This is in strong alignment with the CBS-QB3 equilibrium geometries based on CBS (6-31G(d,p) + CBS-QB3).
These findings indicate that CBS-QB3 is an effective approach for predicting atomization energies, and that post-CCSD(T) energies are adequate for explaining basis set convergence.
TRUFAS (Transit Recognition Using Fast Algorithms) is a wavelet-based technique designed for the quick identification of planetary transits.
TRUFAS includes two stages: a detection stage and a validation stage.
During the detection phase, TRUFAS calculates various detection statistics for a specific light curve.
A detection is announced once the detection statistics meet a predetermined threshold.
A periodogram is generated for every transit detection, and the transit parameters are extracted by fitting a parabola to the peak with the highest amplitude in the periodogram.
TRUFAS can detect planetary transit depths as small as a few percent of the root mean square (RMS) noise in the light curve.
TRUFAS streamlines the transit search process through automation, enhancing efficiency.
During the validation stage, the transit detections are confirmed using simulated planetary systems, and for each validated transit, the False Alarm Probability (FAP) statistics are calculated.
The TRUFAS website provides sample light curves for each detected TRAPPIST-1 transit candidate, along with detection statistics and validated information about the planetary system.

Network communities, which are groups of nodes that exhibit a higher concentration of connections among themselves compared to connections with nodes in other groups, play a crucial role in the structure of networks.
Most existing algorithms primarily identify large clusters, overlooking the intricate structure of smaller communities.
We propose a resolution limit for network clustering and present a hierarchical approach that identifies communities of varying sizes, from large to small, within networks.
The suggested approach begins by identifying super-communities across multiple resolutions, followed by clustering each super-community at the specified resolution.
We assess our approach using both random and real-world networks, demonstrating that it surpasses other leading community detection algorithms.

The complete paper, which includes technical information and data, can be accessed at the following link: https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.09755. The authors of the paper are Ian O. Tolstoy, Han Wang, Paul J. Mucha, and Mihaela Van Con, titled “Network Communities with a High Resolution,” and it was published on December 13, 2017 (arXiv:1711.09755).

Recently, there has been a renewed interest in network clustering, driven by the emergence of diverse network data and the widespread availability of network datasets in various fields, including social media and biology.
Traditionally, research on network communities has concentrated on identifying large clusters or groups of nodes that exhibit high density within the network or networks.
Community detection algorithms are known to be affected by a resolution parameter that influences the level of detail at which clusters are identified.
Generally, higher resolution results in better quality clusters; however, the downside is that more computationally intensive algorithms are required to identify communities at lower resolutions.
In this paper, we present a hierarchical approach to community detection that effectively identifies communities of varying sizes, from large to small, across multiple resolution levels.

The method identifies super-communities, which are large clusters of nodes that exhibit high internal connectivity and density, while maintaining a lower density in relation to other super-communities.
The method subsequently groups the identified super-communities, enhancing the cluster structure for each resolution.
This hierarchical method enables us to identify communities of varying sizes, from large to small, across multiple resolutions.

We showcase the effectiveness of our method on both synthetic and real-world networks, demonstrating its remarkable accuracy in identifying clusters and surpassing leading community detection algorithms.
Noether's theorem is a key principle in physics, asserting that for every symmetry in the laws of physics, there exists a corresponding conserved quantity.
In this letter, we demonstrate that conservation laws can be derived in modified gravity theories through the introduction of hidden symmetries.

We illustrate this for the class of f(R) gravity theories, revealing that the traditional Einstein-Hilbert term found in General Relativity transforms into a modification that lacks a standard Newtonian interpretation.

Due to the non-linear nature of the field equations, the curvature scalar is not a suitable variable for capturing the dynamics of our universe. Instead, a simplified approach that incorporates the evolution of a new scalar degree of freedom is required.

We quantitatively investigate this theory by analyzing the solutions to the field equations. Our findings indicate that this analysis results in modifications to the Poisson equation and alters the distribution of matter density in the universe, potentially giving rise to new physical effects in the large-scale structure of the universe.
We introduce a straightforward and versatile method for identifying exact solutions to the field equations of these theories, and illustrate its application through several specific examples.

We demonstrate that these solutions lead to inhomogeneous stellar distributions characterized by compact cores, a phenomenon that has not been observed in earlier solutions to the field equations of modified gravity theories.
In this paper, we investigate the (0,2) linear sigma model (LSM) within the context of a supermanifold.

The (0,2) LSM serves as a valuable resource for exploring different facets of string theory when it is compactified on non-trivial Ricci-flat backgrounds, including (p,q) 7-branes and similar structures.
The (0,2) LSM is anticipated to offer an accurate representation of the low-energy dynamics associated with certain complete intersections within super Calabi-Yau manifolds.

We extend the concept of the (0,2) Linear Sigma Model (LSM) to the (0,2) gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) on a supermanifold. We demonstrate that the GLSM on a supermanifold is renormalizable provided that the supermanifold is non-compact and possesses a (restricted) gauge symmetry.
We additionally demonstrate that the on-shell (0,2) superfield gauge transformation constitutes a local symmetry of the action.
We will then explore the vacua and certain symmetries of the (0,2) GLSM on a supermanifold, presenting several typical examples of its applications.
Soft Constraint Logic Programming was employed to develop both Unicast and Multicast QoS routing.
This enables the desired quality of service (QoS) to be attained without relying on intermediate routers, thereby decreasing the overall network footprint and minimizing the necessary infrastructure.

Numerical simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach regarding the quality of service provided to the target traffic, as well as a decrease in the overall network footprint and energy usage.
This study builds upon our earlier publication.
[1] also facilitates multicast sessions.
To start, an overview of Soft Constraint Programming was provided to familiarize the reader with the foundational concepts underlying Soft Constraint Logic Programming.
The methodology presented in [1] is further developed to accommodate both Unicast and Multicast QoS traffic.

A numerical example was utilized to demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach concerning the quality of service (QoS) provided to the targeted traffic, as well as the decrease in the overall network footprint and energy usage.
This research received partial funding from the Spanish project TEC2014-51847-R and from Mexican SEP initiatives, specifically awards CONACYT 248735 and SNI 74598.
Relativistic fluctuation theorems comprise a series of equalities that connect the probabilities of various outcomes for systems in thermal equilibrium.
They were hypothesized by Robert Equilibrium in the late 1990s and were first proven in 2003 by Euc59lin Wang and Keiji Saito.
Since then, numerous variants and generalizations have been validated.
The original versions apply solely to the specific scenario of thermodynamic processes characterized by Markov dynamics and system dependencies that are only first-order and time-dependent.
In this context, the relevant theorems are referred to as the classical or non-covariant fluctuation theorems.
Recent studies have demonstrated that, under less stringent conditions, analogous theorems can also be applicable with a covariance factor that is influenced by the system's dynamics.
In this article, we provide a comprehensive derivation of these general theorems, encompassing all relevant covariances.
To verify the findings, numerous established special cases are demonstrated to emerge as limiting instances of the overarching theorem.
This article offers a detailed and updated version of a review originally published in 2014.
Atomic data from the Iron Project (IP) is now accessible online for applications in stellar and plasma physics, quantum chemistry, nuclear physics, materials science, and atomic science.

The initiative was a longstanding joint effort involving numerous institutions aimed at gathering and structuring precise, reliable, and thoroughly verified atomic data for all elements with atomic masses ranging from helium to copper.
The information has been structured into user-friendly databases, featuring customized HTTP and HTTPS endpoints for easy navigation.
Here, we present data on the radiative transition rates and collision strengths for Ca II.
The data have been verified for reliability and consistency by comparing them with other sources and our earlier data on similar elements.
In cases where data was not accessible from other sources, we have conducted our own calculations and provided estimates of the uncertainty to facilitate modeling and analysis by others.
Comprehensive information about the data and its organization, along with references to the original sources, is available at https://doi.org/10.26208/data.0000002329.
The NUGA galaxy survey is a comprehensive integral field spectroscopy investigation focused on 32 early-type galaxies, conducted with the SSO Telescope.
In this section, we provide the data and analysis related to the only spiral galaxy in our sample, NGC4569.
Our analysis shows that most of the molecular gas in NGC 4569 is located within a significant large-scale bar.
This demonstrated that it was causing a bidirectional, slow-rotating wave within the potential, directing gas inward.
The molecular gas in this bar is dense, with a deconvolved size of around 1.1 kpc.
By employing a straightforward rotating bar model, we demonstrate that the observed size aligns well with what is anticipated based on the bar's strength.
We observe molecular hydrogen in two secondary resonances, lending additional support for the presence of a substantial bar at the center of NGC 4569.
These are the initial large-scale observations of molecular hydrogen in a spiral galaxy.
The discussion focuses on the bar located at the center of NGC4569 and its connection to the observed molecular gas.
Quarks were believed to be fundamental particles that engage in interactions via the strong force.
In experiments, only two of the six quarks, known as up and down quarks, are found in stable particles (protons and neutrons) within ordinary matter.
The remaining four quarks, known as strange, up, down, and bottom, exist in structures called hadrons, which combine to create matter exclusively via the strong force.
The strong force holds the quarks together within protons and neutrons, which are types of hadrons.
The mass of a hadron is referred to as its binding energy.
Quarks are thought to be particles that function like small magnets, and each exists in six distinct "colors" representing the symmetry group SU(3) in quantum chromodynamics (QCD).
The six distinct "colors" associated with a quark relate to the six components of a mathematical structure known as an octet.
Each flavor of the octet has a distinct charge and mass fraction, allowing us to define the up and down quarks (with charges of 2/3 and -1/3, respectively, in relation to their mass).
The other flavors—strange, up, down, and bottom—each correspond to a specific named hadron.
The names of these six hadrons can be combined to form larger hadrons.
For instance, the bottom quark possesses a small share of the charge of the bottom hadron, which makes the bottom hadron a weakly interacting particle that includes a bottom quark.

In the framework of the standard model of particle physics, quarks are considered to be point-like particles, with their interactions governed by quantum chromodynamics (QCD), which characterizes the strong force acting between them.
The prevailing theory of the strong interaction, known as quantum chromodynamics (QCD), effectively explains numerous aspects of hadrons, such as their energy levels and decay processes.
A significant consequence of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is that up and down quarks can never exist independently; instead, they always combine to form structures known as hadrons.
This essential interaction among quarks is referred to as "confinement."

According to the phenomenological quark model, the most fundamental particles in the universe are the up, down, and strange quarks, along with their associated hadrons, collectively referred to as hadrons.
A powerful force that holds quarks together creates hadrons.
Hadronic matter is the common form of matter composed of hadrons.
It exists across the universe, present in planets, stars, and galaxies.
To investigate this phenomenon, nuclear physicists examine particles that are either fragments of hadrons, including beta particles and pi mesons, or complete hadrons, such as protons and neutrons.
The nuclei of hydrogen and helium are referred to as ordinary matter.
Quarks can also be found within other particles, but their behavior remains somewhat unclear.
Due to their significantly greater mass compared to the quarks that constitute ordinary matter, these "sea quarks" are predominantly located within hadrons, which hold them together.

A novel unstable mode known as the R-mode was identified in the linear analyses conducted by Balbus & Hawley (1992) and Hameury, Menou, & Dubus (2013) regarding rapidly rotating neutron stars that are accretors orbiting a black hole.
These modes exhibit a very low characteristic frequency and can develop over the time frame of an accretion event.
We provide the findings from our time-dependent numerical simulations of the unstable growth of R-mode instabilities in the atmosphere of a neutron star located near a black hole.
We track the dynamic progression of the unstable modes throughout the nonlinear phase of their development.
Our research indicates that nonlinear effects considerably reduce the growth rate of the R-mode compared to what is anticipated from linear projections.
Specifically, the growth rate becomes significantly smaller than the inverse accretion time, which is the defining time scale of the issue.

We contend that the nonlinear progression of the R-mode instability is still a dynamic field of study and may significantly influence the evolution of neutron star spin rates and the outflows associated with gamma-ray bursts.
Astronomers have long been aware that the universe is permeated by tiny particles of radiation termed cosmic microwave background radiation.
This radiation holds significant scientific importance because it represents the final light emitted during the Big Bang, allowing researchers to investigate the conditions of the early universe.
Recently, researchers have created a model that explains how quantum mechanical effects in the universe could produce this background radiation.
The model depicts the universe as a vast sea of zero-point fluctuations, where particles occupy every conceivable virtual position within this expanse.
As the universe expands and cools, virtual particles are more likely to occupy the lowest energy states, resulting in a background of virtual radiation.
This model has a significant drawback: it portrayed the universe as a series of waves instead of a collection of particles.
This can be compared to representing the ocean as a group of sticks floating on the surface of a pot of boiling water.
The waves represent the motion of the ocean, while the sticks symbolize the particles in a boiling pot of water.
The particles described by the model, which represent the waves of the universe, have not yet been observed.
In this model, the particles in the boiling pot of water represent the photons of the cosmic microwave background radiation.
As the universe cools, photons are more likely to settle into their lowest-energy states, reaching equilibrium with the frigid surroundings.

As the universe cools to a temperature of 3000 K, the photons cease to remain in equilibrium with the quantum fluctuations of radiation. This disruption causes them to begin free-streaming, as they travel from areas of high density to regions of lower density.
This is similar to a water bottle forgotten in the cold.
As the bottle cools, water molecules start to settle towards the bottom, creating an area of lower density compared to the surrounding air.
In this study, we examine an altered model of this phenomenon, where the particles (photons) remain stationary while the background radiation is in motion.
In this scenario, the universe resembles a "frozen sea" in which particles accumulate at the seabed, while radiation waves persistently ripple across the cosmos.

In this model, as the universe cools, the radiation waves persistently travel through space, while the particles have settled into a state akin to the bottom of the ocean. This results in areas of varying density throughout the universe, some regions being more concentrated and others less so.
This offers a process through which the universe can shift from a state of thermal equilibrium to a nonequilibrium condition, characterized by a cooling-driven phase transition.

A proposed autonomous distributed admission control scheme for IEEE 802.11 DCF intelligently allocates channel capacity to enhance wireless medium utilization efficiency and effectively maximizes the available bandwidth capacity.
The admission control system is made up of a managing mechanism and a regulated algorithm.
The controlling mechanism segments the entire network into several virtual channels of a predetermined size by allocating a variety of channel access priorities.
Every station within the network detects the wireless medium and determines the appropriate transmission data rates.

The controlled algorithm identifies the stations by forming connections within the control mechanism based on their network needs, and subsequently shifts the entire network across various virtual channels based on the scheduling outcomes.
Simulation results indicate that the efficiency of channel utilization can be significantly improved.

The complete text of this paper can be accessed at http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.02605. This paper introduces an autonomous distributed admission control scheme for IEEE 802.11 DCF, designed to intelligently allocate channel capacity. This approach aims to enhance the efficiency of wireless medium utilization and maximize the use of available bandwidth.
Initially, the entire network is segmented into several virtual channels of a predetermined size by allocating various levels of channel access priorities.
Every station in the network detects the wireless medium and determines the appropriate transmission data rates.

Additionally, the controlled algorithm determines which stations will establish connections within the controlling mechanism based on their network requirements and adjusts the entire network across various virtual channels based on the scheduling outcomes.
The simulation results demonstrate that channel utilization efficiency can be significantly improved.

The complete text of this paper can be accessed at http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.02605. This paper presents an autonomous distributed admission control scheme for IEEE 802.11 DCF.
