IEEE 802.11e has become the predominant standard for Wi-Fi network management (WNM).
However, depending on asymmetric-bandwidth leasing for announcements and confirmations may put low-traffic stations (LTSs) at a disadvantage.
In this paper, we introduce a design for an efficient layer-2 bandwidth sharing mechanism for IEEE 802.11e, aimed at minimizing the implicit bandwidth leasing by long-term services (LTSs).
The mechanisms were carried out and assessed in a simulated 802.11e IBSS.
The findings indicate that our mechanisms can decrease the L5-L14 latency of the emulated IBSS by approximately 13.5% on a saturated channel when compared to the leading unloader.
Moreover, our mechanisms do not negatively impact the Wi-Fi quality of service for non-LTS clients, while ensuring high fairness and low leasing costs for LTS clients.
This study introduces a cosmological model that explores the simultaneous evolution of quasars, supermassive black holes (SMBHs), and elliptical galaxies.

This framework is essential for comprehensively understanding the interactions between quasars and supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and their host galaxies, as well as how the co-evolution of these elements influences the host galaxies themselves.

We introduce a hierarchical model for galaxy mergers that encompasses both dry and wet mergers, demonstrating that this model inherently leads to the formation of elliptical galaxies with substantial bulges.
Additionally, we contend that this framework is capable of simultaneously replicating both the observed abundance and evolution of elliptical galaxies, as well as the quasar luminosity function.

Finally, we demonstrate that significant mergers can effectively ignite both quasar and radio activity. This radio activity serves as a sustained source of feedback, which can inhibit the growth of both supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and elliptical galaxies.
This research is carried out under the H2020 Twinning program, titled "Active Galactic Nuclei Connecting Fundamental Physics and the Universe," with contract number 654004 (SURF).
NGC 1904 is a globular cluster within the Milky Way, situated roughly 18,000 light-years away from Earth.
Although previous research has examined the cluster across various passbands, this represents the first thorough investigation of the entire cluster within the blue and green regions of the spectrum.
The cluster appears to be somewhat brighter and larger than indicated by previous studies in the blue spectrum, with the brightest stars reaching a visual magnitude of 8.5.
The most luminous stars were found to possess a Blue Straggler Branch, which is indicative of stars transitioning away from the main sequence in their evolutionary process.
The mass function for the bright stars aligns with a Kroupa profile, revealing a departure from the typical distribution, which the authors attribute to the effects of mass segregation.
The cluster's radial profile was analyzed in the core, intermediate, and outer regions.

While the density of stars consistently decreases with increasing distance from the cluster center in the inner regions, the profile levels off in the intermediate area, revealing a distinct separation of the sub-structures.

The analysis of velocity dispersion revealed variations across the core, intermediate, and outer regions. In the intermediate region, the velocity dispersion was observed to increase with radius, while in the outer regions, it exhibited a decline, clearly delineating the boundary between the core and the halo.
The star OO Serpentis is categorized as a young Be star.
It features a surrounding dust decretion disk along with an eruptive counterpart that is detectable as electromagnetic radiation.
In this paper, I discuss the star's outburst that occurred between 1995 and 2006, followed by a phase of low activity starting in 2005, and a resurgence of outburst activity that began in 2012.

By utilizing infrared observations from Spitzer and millimeter observations from ALMA, I investigate the characteristics of the ejecta and its surrounding environment, enabling me to propose a model for the outburst and its subsequent evolution.
Since 2005, OO Serpentis has entered a new phase of reduced activity, yet this has not halted the formation of new ejecta.
Currently, the dust deceleration disk moves outward until it attains a stable distance of 2.5 A.U. from the central star.
The outburst has once again become noticeable since 2012.
Based on the infrared observations, I demonstrate that the star's brightening resulted in the expulsion of new ejecta and an increased rate of ejection throughout the entire duration of the outburst.
By utilizing millimeter observations, I analyze the ejecta and the density of the surrounding medium around the star.

I propose a model for the ejection of the ejecta that is based on the changes in the decretion disk of dust. This model accounts for the sequence and temporal correlation observed between the dust and the ejecta.
This paper examines Lorentzian and signature-altering branes within the framework of various higher spin theories.

We begin by examining the action of multiple parallel branes within the context of a general higher spin theory. We will outline the equations of motion, investigate the scenarios involving Lorentzian and signature-changing branes, and derive general formulations for various geometric conserved charges.
We examine particular instances of the higher spin superalgebra $hs(n|n)$ and $ds(4|1)$ in the context of general matter. We analyze their Killing spinor equations and focus on specific signatures.

Our findings contribute to the exploration of AdS/CFT correspondence and holography, illustrating that the conserved charges in higher spin theories exhibit analogous characteristics to those found in gravitational theories on AdS and de Sitter backgrounds.

Numerous papers with comparable titles can be found in the arXiv.org repository. In this work, we introduce a fresh analysis of Lorentzian and signature-changing branes within the framework of various higher spin theories.

The WMAP satellite has identified a cold spot in the polarized sky, exhibiting a lower brightness temperature of 1.3 K, in contrast to the average temperature of 2.2 K observed in surrounding areas. The lack of related structures in both the unpolarized and tabulated maps has given rise to multiple theories regarding the origin and nature of this cold spot.
One possibility is that it stems from a systematic effect in the WMAP data.
Historical observations have noted such systematic effects, and the WMAP team is currently undertaking a thorough investigation into potential residual thermal noise and sources of contamination.
Another possibility is that the cold spot indicates the presence of a previously unknown type of structure in the universe.
If this is true, it would have profound consequences for our understanding of cosmology and the early universe.
We conducted an in-depth analysis of temperature and polarization data from 84 extragalactic radio sources using WMAP data to investigate potential signatures of the observed cold spot.

We do not observe any such features, and thus we conclude that the reported low temperature region is not a systematic artifact in the WMAP data, but rather indicates an actual characteristic of the Universe.

Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), commonly referred to as Long-Term Memory, relies on the activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) at the presynaptic level and the synthesis of proteins at the postsynaptic level.
Maintenance depends on the activity of NMDA receptors for the synthesis of new proteins.
In this study, we introduce a model of late L-LTP that includes these three fundamental components.
The model is capable of generating long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, similarly to what is seen in late-stage long-term potentiation (L-LTP).
Therefore, the model could serve as a valuable tool in clarifying the fundamental mechanisms of late L-LTP.

Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), often referred to as Long-Term Memory, relies on the activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) in the presynaptic neuron, as well as the synthesis of proteins in the postsynaptic neuron.
Maintenance necessitates the activity of NMDA receptors and the synthesis of new proteins.
We propose a model for late L-LTP that integrates these three fundamental elements.
The model is capable of generating long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, phenomena that are likewise seen in late long-term potentiation (L-LTP).
Consequently, the model can serve as a valuable tool for clarifying the fundamental mechanisms of late L-LTP.
The model consists of three components: the presynaptic element, the postsynaptic element, and the interaction between them.
The presynaptic component features an mGluR that activates in response to a rise in the concentration of a presynaptic neurotransmitter.
This initiates the mobilization of calcium through a diacylglycerol/protein kinase C signaling cascade.
The influx of calcium leads to the production of essential proteins that play a key role in the maintenance of L-LTP.
The postsynaptic component involves the synthesis of glutamate receptors, which have a half-life of a few hours.

Ultimately, the interaction between the two components leads to the occurrence of long-term depression (L-LTD) when there is a reduction in the concentrations of both postsynaptic glutamate and presynaptic neurotransmitters.
Our findings indicate that this model is capable of inducing long-term depression, as well as long-term potentiation comparable to late L-LTP.
In summary, we believe that this model could serve as a valuable resource for understanding the fundamental mechanisms of late L-LTP.
Acknowledgments This research was funded by NSF grants 1719653, 1719564, 1820822, 1834991, and 1900094.
We extend our gratitude to Dr. Vladimir Zabalon for his feedback on the manuscript.

Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), often referred to as Long-Term Memory, relies on the activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) in the presynaptic neurons, as well as the synthesis of proteins in the postsynaptic neurons.
Maintenance depends on the activity of NMDA receptors and the synthesis of new proteins.
In this study, we introduce a model of late L-LTP that includes these three fundamental components.
The model has the potential to induce long-term depression (L-LTD).
Dying radio galaxies serve as valuable cosmological instruments, as they can help map the large-scale structure of the universe.

These galaxies exhibit diminished radio emissions linked to their active nuclei, along with some hot-spot activity, displaying a distinct cutoff at the boundary of the large-scale structure where the galaxy is located.
Although dying radio galaxies hold significant importance for cosmology, there are currently no well-defined samples available for statistical study.
We conducted a search for these sources using publicly accessible data from the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array archive.
We have identified 19 sources exhibiting fading radio emissions that resemble those anticipated from dying radio galaxies.
We explore the significance of this discovery for the investigation of large-scale structures and the implications it holds for future searches for similar sources.
This research was conducted under the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array public science program 13B254.
We would like to express our gratitude to the array staff, along with the members of the VLASS Project Office and the McGee Division of the NRAO, for their assistance in developing this program.
A de Haas-van Alphen investigation has been conducted on the filled skutterudite compounds PrOs₄As₁₂ and LaOs₄As₁₂.
Filled skutterudite compounds demonstrate heavy Fermion behavior, making PrOs4As12 and LaOs4As12 potential candidates for the realization of a Kondo lattice system.

We noted a nearly mass-independent aspect of the field-dependent magnetic susceptibility in both compounds down to 1.8 K. This nearly mass-independent component is probably a result of the crystalline electric field (CEF) effect.
The CEF level scheme has been examined, revealing the presence of nine excited levels.
This research is a fundamental experiment for comprehending quantum criticality in filled skutterudite systems.

Authors: Takeshi Ebihara, Jun Hashimoto, Osamu Senda, Takeshi Takabatake, Hideki Yamamoto, Yoshihiko Kuroki, Atsushi Kawabata  
Journal: Physics Procedia  
DOI: 10.1016/j.proc.2016.10.075
In this paper, we explore the challenge of identifying the minimal probability of ruin within a jump-diffusion risk model.
We offer a description of the lowest probability of ruin through a convex game that includes both a stopping game and a control game.
At each stage, the player must decide whether to continue with the risk process until reaching the point of ruin or to stop the game and secure a certain level of safe liquidation wealth.
In the control game, the strategy selected by the first player dictates both the timing and the magnitude of the jump process.

By utilizing an expanded form of Sion's theorem in the context of this game, we can define the value function of the stopping game as the sole classical solution to a degenerate elliptic partial differential equation.
Ultimately, we demonstrate that this value function represents both the lowest probability of ruin and the singular highest probability of survival.
This study is relevant for risk managers, researchers, and students focused on issues concerning the calculation of the minimum probability of ruin within a jump-diffusion risk model.
Magnetic fields exist in the majority of stars and planets, significantly influencing their evolution.
There was considerably less understanding of magnetic fields in systems that did not exhibit clear, collimated, or organized magnetic fields, like those found in stars and planets.
Observations of both continuum and line emissions from numerous low-mass pre-main-sequence stars, known as T Tauri stars, have shown substantial magnetic fields present in these systems.
The predominant configuration for the field in these systems is a dipole that is aligned with the axis of stellar rotation.
In this study, we showcase Zeeman-Doppler imaging to investigate the existence and characteristics of a dipole magnetic field in the T Tauri star Hen 3-4008.
The dipole field is obscured by the large inner disk but becomes visible in the outer disk, where it is accompanied by slow magnetoacoustic waves that permeate the disk.
We provide a quantitative analysis of the field characteristics and establish a lower limit for the magnetic field strength of Hen 3-4008, estimating it to be around 650 G.
The presence of dark matter is confirmed by its gravitational influence on the visible matter found in galaxies.
The origins of dark matter remain a mystery.
The most widely accepted explanation for its nature, known as the cold dark matter theory, asserts that it consists of elementary particles that do not emit or absorb electromagnetic radiation.
Observational evidence has confirmed the presence of dark matter in clusters or aggregates that are sufficiently large to be detected in both particles and galaxies.
It is thought that these clusters develop through the gravitational interactions between their individual particles and galaxies.
Because dark matter's components neither emit nor absorb light, directly observing them has proven difficult.
Examining the dynamics of these clusters can thus enhance our understanding of dark matter's properties.
B514 is a globular cluster situated in the M31 galaxy, roughly 25,000 light-years away from our planet.
By utilizing the Hubble Space Telescope, I have concluded that B514 possesses a further extended halo that, according to its structural and dynamic features, is most likely made up of dark matter.
I have found that the dark matter halo has an average density of 0.105 halo particles per cubic light-year and spans a diameter of 1.33 kiloparsecs, equivalent to 17,650 light-years.
An interaction between a muon, electron, or tau particle neutrino and a nuclear target can produce a variety of outcomes.
In neutrino oscillation experiments, a key focus is on the channels where a charged current interaction results in a charged lepton signature, along with missing transverse momentum.
In this paper, we show that these channels can be simplified to a complex symplectic invariant that we refer to as s.

This invariant's structure enables us to anticipate the configuration of the associated charged current neutrino interaction matrix within the Standard Model, specifically the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix.
We utilize experimental data to analyze the leading order structure of the CKM matrix and show that it closely aligns with the structure predicted by the invariant.
We conduct our analysis on precision global fits of the neutrino mixing matrix and demonstrate that the resulting structure predicted by s aligns with the data at a significance level of 1.7 sigma.
We also explore how this result relates to higher-dimensional physics and flavor symmetry.

This paper introduces the development of WHAM (WENO-HARDM), a new code designed for general relativistic hydrodynamics.
This paper outlines the numerical methods utilized in the code and discusses various challenges faced along with the corresponding solutions discovered during the development process.
The code is designed in a modular way, enabling easy extensions to other hydrodynamic equations, embedding equations, and mathematical flux functions.
The authors conducted various tests on the code to showcase its capability to effectively capture both smooth solutions and physical discontinuities.
The results align well with the exact solutions and the existing literature on various hydrodynamic equations.
WHAM can be accessed at https://bitbucket.org/carrerr/wham.
The master repository houses all the development code, whereas the documentation can be found in the https://github.com/carrerr/wham/tree/master/doc directory.

WHAM: A WENO-based General Relativistic Numerical Scheme I: Hydrodynamics  
Hydrodynamics refers to the study of fluid motion, as explained by the principles of fluid mechanics.
Fluid mechanics, in contrast, focuses on the study of fluid behavior without considering radiation or mechanical effects.

The behavior of a viscous fluid is characterized by the hydrodynamic equations, which include the continuity equation that ensures the conservation of mass; the fluid velocity, which reflects Newton's law of motion along with conditions such as no flow across boundaries (no-slip condition) or along channels (zero shear); and the conservation of momentum, which accounts for forces generated by contact friction and other external factors not covered in the mass equation.
General relativity explores how gravity influences the movement of light.

General relativity stands as one of the most thorough and successful frameworks in physics, encompassing all known types of energy, which include mass-energy, matter, electromagnetic energy, and nuclear energy.
It also explains the interactions within spacetime and how spacetime is formed.
The theory emerged from efforts to harmonize Isaac Newton's concepts of a universal and elegantly unified theory of gravity with the accurate depiction of the movements of planets and stars.
Specifically, general relativity provides a precise account of how light behaves in the context of planets and stars, whereas Newton's theory seems insufficient to explain these phenomena.

Noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is a crucial element that is frequently overlooked in the examination of this unique state of quantum matter.
Theoretical predictions suggest that both emission and absorption noise are present in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE).
Although emission noise can influence transport measurements within the sample, absorption noise does not have this effect and can be detected using noise spectroscopy.

We introduce two different experimental approaches for conducting this noise spectroscopy: one employs microwave radiation, while the other uses optical Raman scattering. Both methods demonstrate strong quantitative alignment with theoretical predictions concerning emission and absorption noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE).

Noise spectroscopy serves as a crucial tool for investigating transport phenomena in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) and will facilitate future explorations of many-body dynamics within this quantum many-body system.
This research on noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is significant because investigations of this unique quantum state frequently neglect the noise-related aspects of the FQHE.
Emission noise may influence transport measurements within the sample, whereas absorption noise does not affect these measurements and can be detected using noise spectroscopy.

We showcase two different experimental approaches to noise spectroscopy: one utilizing microwave radiation and the other employing optical Raman scattering. Both methods demonstrate strong quantitative consistency with theoretical predictions regarding emission and absorption noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE).

We explore the collapse of extremely massive stars, beginning with a stellar mass equivalent to that of the Sun and rotating at speeds 600 times that of light, ultimately leading to the formation of black holes within the framework of full general relativity.

These collapses happen in an area characterized by extremely high angular momentum, where the hole creates a breach in the sky and diminishes to a Schwarzschild radius of approximately 30 km, a point at which General Relativity dictates that it must attain infinite mass.

We conduct simulations at resolutions of up to 2048x1024, demonstrating that the fluid adopts a prolate shape, exhibiting a maximum radius of approximately 1000 meters, alongside a slowly rotating inner core with a radius of a few meters.

After an initial phase lasting approximately 0.5 milliseconds, the collapse progresses in a manner strikingly akin to the direct collision of two black holes, one with a mass of 30 solar masses and the other with 10 solar masses. This event features an apparent horizon roughly 20 kilometers in diameter and is associated with an estimated energy release of about 2.5% of the total mass, which aligns closely with results from earlier perturbative calculations.

We investigate the characteristics of the black holes that are created and demonstrate that various physical parameters, including irreducible mass, rotational parameter, curvature invariant, and surface gravity at the event horizon, align closely with the values derived from perturbative calculations, even in the case of the final, non-perturbative, rotating star.
Web data has progressed alongside the development of the internet, incorporating new concepts like social networks and mobile applications.
The amount of data is growing daily, necessitating new research in data management to facilitate effective data analytics.
This paper presents a distributed data model designed for the integration of web data within data warehouses.

The primary benefit of this model is that all data related to a website is consolidated into a single row within the target relational database, simplifying the process of executing joins between this table and others.
This model employs case-change style rules to create additional columns in the base table, representing new concepts, and these rules can be easily extended to incorporate further concepts.

The proposed model has been implemented using a MySQL database, and its performance has been assessed with real-world data. Results indicate that this model is capable of managing large volumes of web data more effectively than alternative models.

Recently, several anomalies have been discovered in the WMAP data, including alignments between areas of high (positive) and low (negative) signed intensities and the directions of the solar wind, as well as correlations between temperature and components of the KQ75 oriented dataset from WMAP.
These anomalies are commonly interpreted as indirect indications of electromagnetic interference and potential contamination from dust within the Solar System.
In this study, we present the identification of various additional alignment and intensity anomalies in the WMAP data that have not been previously documented and are more challenging to account for.
We offer a credible physical explanation for these anomalies, attributing them to interference caused by artificial radio signals.
We show that the same interference effects are also responsible for the anomalies recently observed in the signed-intensity and cross-power spectra.
The interference we discuss here is likely attributable to artificial radio signals within the frequency ranges of 128 - 137 MHz, 143 - 149 MHz, and 333 - 349 MHz.
During the period from May 2003 to November 2003, the radio waves from these sources traveled from North America into the northern hemisphere of the sky, where the WMAP spacecraft is positioned.

In this paper, we introduce a construction of free fermions for supergroup WZNW models, utilizing a free fermion resolution of supergroups and incorporating a spectral flow that connects models at varying levels.
We present a free field realization of the WZNW model that is derived from the free fermion approach.

We calculate correlation functions through the operator product expansion and demonstrate that our findings align with the established results for the supergroup \( GL(1|1) \) and the superconformal model with a central charge of \( c=6 \).
In particular, we validate the accuracy of the recently introduced four-point functions that adhere to general symmetry and global consistency conditions.

We further explore the application of this method to create free fermions for supergroup WZNW models involving various supergroups. Additionally, we demonstrate that models with a broad range of supergroups can be derived as WZNW models utilizing free fermions.

Bipolar spintronics merges the benefits of ferromagnetic materials with spin electronics by leveraging both the spin of electrons and that of holes.
This approach utilizes spin-orbit interaction (SOI) to create or detect spin polarization, while ferromagnetism can serve as a means for information storage.
The initial application of bipolar spintronics was the observation of the spin Hall effect in 1977.

Since that time, extensive research has been carried out in this area, leading to the proposal of numerous applications such as the anomalous Hall effect, pure spin current injection, and spintronics-based logic.
This paper provides a comprehensive overview of bipolar spintronics, covering aspects from spin injection to spin-controlled logic.

We begin with a concise overview of spin and the concept of the spin Hall effect.
Next, we explore the discovery and initial experimental investigation of the spin Hall effect, which encompasses phenomena such as the anomalous Hall effect, spin rectification, and spin pumping.
The last two effects have been acknowledged as a crucial basis for future research on spin transport and its applications.
We introduce theoretical models for the spin Hall effect, drawing from classical mechanics and spin drift-diffusion equations.
These models serve as the foundation for additional analytical and numerical investigations into spin transport.
This overview examines the experiments and theoretical studies related to spin pumping in thin magnetic films.
Next, we will discuss the experimental investigations of the anomalous Hall effect and spin rectification in thin films.
The significance of the topological term in the context of the anomalous Hall effect is examined.
The review also covers spin rectification via spin mixing and transmission.
A comparison was made between the advantages and disadvantages of these two effects in various applications.
The emergence of topological phases in the electron system with spin-orbit interaction is also discussed.
The topological phase was associated with the topological spin, as well as the anomalous and topological Hall effects.
We subsequently explore the injection of spin current through the lens of the spin Hall effect.
An overview of the direct observation of the spin Hall effect in metallic systems is presented.
We additionally discuss the spin Hall effect in relation to semiconductors, magnetic semiconductors, and topological insulators.
An overview of the recent discovery of surface states in topological insulators is provided.
The discussion then turns to the techniques used to detect spin accumulation.
An overview of research on spin dynamics in semiconductors is presented.

Next, we introduce the application of bipolar spintronics, which encompasses spin-charge conversion devices, exchange interaction-based devices, tunnel magnetoresistance-based devices, and spin-based technologies.
Neutrinos play a crucial role in the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics.
Their interactions are characterized by the Lagrangian λ–μ+ν(−χ+ρ), where λ, μ, and ν represent the coupling constants of the three lepton families, while χ and ρ denote the scalar fields.
The source of these couplings was not explained within the framework of the Standard Model.
The absence of self-interactions among neutrinos in the Lagrangian is due to a property known as lepton number symmetry.

However, we demonstrate that the observed neutrino oscillations are most accurately accounted for by the spontaneous breaking of this symmetry at a scale of θ ≤ 10^-10 GeV, beneath which the effective theory exhibits radiatively broken symmetry.
We determine the value of θ along with various cosmological parameters, and our findings indicate that the most basic iterations of this model align well with recent data.
We will also provide a brief overview of variations of this model that incorporate additional scalar fields, as well as outline the steps for testing this model.

We demonstrate that the observed neutrino oscillations can be most accurately explained by the spontaneous breaking of this symmetry at a scale of θ ≤ 10^−10 GeV. Below this scale, the effective theory exhibits radiatively induced symmetry breaking.
We determine θ and various cosmological parameters, discovering that the most straightforward versions of this model align with the latest data.
We also provide a brief overview of different versions of this model that incorporate additional scalar fields, along with proposed methods for testing it.
Gigantic black holes can be found in all substantial galaxies.
They expand over time as they accumulate more matter.
The masses of black holes can be estimated by employing the fundamental plane of black hole activity.
The model was developed using three key parameters: the velocity dispersion of the host galaxy, the stellar velocity dispersion, and the radius of the black hole's sphere of influence.
The first two were measured for the galaxy, whereas the third can be estimated based on the mass of the black hole.
The latter two are closely related and can be utilized to estimate the mass of the black hole.
This estimation has been conducted on a vast sample of galaxies, revealing that larger galaxies tend to host more massive black holes on average.

This correlation can be represented by a linear equation of the form: \( M_{BH} = A \times M_{spheroid} + B \), where \( M_{BH} \) denotes the mass of the black hole, \( M_{spheroid} \) represents the mass of the spheroid, \( A \) is a coefficient approximately equal to 7, and \( B \) is a constant.
This relationship was observed to hold true for galaxies of all Hubble classifications, particularly for early-type galaxies.

The relationships between the host galaxy characteristics and the spheroid were more pronounced than those associated with black hole mass, which may be attributed to the growth of black holes being driven by mergers.
The variation in the relationship can be minimized by incorporating an additional observable, specifically the luminosity of the spheroid.
The former can be estimated by utilizing the velocity dispersion and the radius of the sphere of influence, both of which are necessary for the latter.
The B-band luminosity of the galaxy can be used to estimate the latter.

It has been observed that the scatter in the black hole mass - spheroid luminosity relation is considerably lower compared to other relations, with the best-fit coefficient being closer to 10. This can be attributed to more precise measurements and reduced intrinsic scatter in the spheroid luminosity.
It has been proposed that the relationship between black hole mass and spheroid luminosity could serve as a novel standard for estimating black hole mass.

Free core nutation, sometimes referred to as temporal nutation, is a relatively rapid aspect of Earth's rotation.
It is directly related to the axial wobble, which is influenced by the planet's mass and moment of inertia.
Satellites have measured temporal nutation with remarkable precision, allowing for the detection of the Free Core Nutation Frequency (FCNF).
FCNF results from changes in the Earth's axis of rotation within the framework of the Free Core Nutation Mode.
The amplitude of FCNF can fluctuate over time, providing insights into the dynamics of Earth's core.
In this study, we examine a pre-existing database of FCNF observations collected from space.
We employ two techniques to isolate the FCNF signal from the surrounding noise.
The initial approach utilizes statistical hypothesis testing to assess the significance of the FCNF signal.
The second approach utilized empirical mode decomposition to identify the components of the FCNF signal.
The outcomes from both approaches are in agreement and indicate that the amplitude of FCNF changes over time.
This suggests that the dynamics of Earth's core could be of significant interest to researchers.
This study reexamines the dynamics of ideal fluids on Lie groups through the lens of control theory.
It is widely recognized that these theories can be derived from the Lagrangian formulation of the renowned Euler equation on the diffeomorphism group of a three-dimensional Riemannian manifold.

A corresponding Hamiltonian framework is presented through the utilization of Lie groupoids and Lagrangian mechanics on these structures. Specific constructions are provided for several significant scenarios, including fluid dynamics on Lie groups, Newtonian gravity on the special orthogonal group and the general linear group, as well as the classical ECSK theory of non-relativistic gravity.

In the Hamiltonian framework, the fluid dynamics on Lie groups and ideal hydrodynamics are represented by a Lie groupoid. In this context, fluid dynamics is a specific instance where the source of the gauge groupoid morphism is the diffeomorphism group of the fluid domain.

Specifically, within the particle framework, the fluid dynamics on Lie groups and the principles of ideal hydrodynamics can be understood as emerging from a deformation quantization of the corresponding source groupoid.

It has been demonstrated that the Schrödinger equation, which outlines the dynamics of quantum mechanics, can be derived as the geodesic equation for the magnetic connection in deformation quantization.

This allows for the creation of a mechanical system that achieves ideal hydrodynamics on a large scale, specifically one that displays the geodesic flow of a particular left-invariant metric on the solution groupoid.
The resulting system is explicitly demonstrated in the context of ideal fluid dynamics on the special orthogonal group.

It has also been demonstrated that the constructed system is Hamiltonian in relation to a modified symplectic structure, which aligns with that of Dubois-Viallet on the Lie group associated with the special orthogonal group.
Several precise solutions were also provided.
This paper presents a background study for the pn-CCD detector used in the CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST).
The CAST experiment aims to detect solar axions by assessing their likelihood of converting into invisible photons within the magnetic field of the Southern solar farm.
The pn-CCD is one of the detector systems utilized in CAST.
The system comprises two hexagonal planes of silicon photomultipliers featuring a 0.85 mm depleted surface detector, which encompasses 95% of the overall sensitive area.
This study enhances and finalizes the model-independent background analysis of the detector introduced in a prior publication.
The anticipated rates for gamma-ray-induced signals in the silicon detector and the surrounding passive materials have been calculated and compared with the observed background levels.
The resulting rates were utilized to establish new limits on photon backgrounds for CAST.

A background study for the pn-CCD detector of the CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST) was introduced.
The CAST experiment sought to detect solar axions by assessing the likelihood of their conversion into invisible photons within the magnetic field of the Southern solar farm.
The pn-CCD is a detector system utilized in CAST.
It comprises two hexagonal planes of silicon photomultipliers featuring a 0.85 mm depleted surface detector, which covers 95% of the overall sensitive area.
This study enhances and finalizes the model-independent background analysis for the detector, as described in a prior publication.
The anticipated rates of gamma-ray induced signals in the silicon detector and the adjacent passive material are calculated and contrasted with the recorded background.
The resulting rates are utilized to establish new constraints on photon backgrounds for CAST.
A diverse range of masses, varying from 3 to 18 M☉, has been observed for single stars.
This range covers 4 to 18 M_odot for white dwarfs.
The maximum masses of neutron stars have been estimated to range between 2.2 and 2.5 solar masses (M⊙), although this figure comes with considerable uncertainty.
In binary systems, creating such massive compact objects is significantly more challenging since a greater quantity of matter needs to be compressed over an extended period.
The origin of these extremely massive objects is still uncertain.
It has been suggested that these extremely massive objects could be the remnants of enormous Population III stars.
These enormous Population III stars likely emerged in regions of the early universe that were devoid of metals, as a result of the bottom-up formation process for these massive entities.
Extremely massive Population III stars are thought to have formed with a mass ranging from about 40 to 200 solar masses.
When these extraordinarily massive Population III stars run out of nuclear fuel, they can conclude their life cycle as highly dense compact objects.
At present, the available models for these enormous compact objects are quite limited, which hinders our comprehension of their evolution.
Current models of very massive compact objects postulate that these objects maintain a constant mass, which is equivalent to the initial mass of their progenitor.
Nevertheless, a more accurate model for the masses of compact objects would consider the potential loss of mass that can occur during their formation.
Magnetodielectric materials that exhibit substantial magneto-optical and dielectric losses enable the propagation of traveling waves that experience both attenuation and refraction.

When the resonant loss characteristics of these materials are broadened due to radiative processes, the ensuing enhancement of the local field and degradation of the media can significantly reduce refraction and absorption.

In this study, we theoretically and experimentally showcase the phenomenon of negative refraction and the reduction of absorption in a resonant plasmon-radiative medium, which is founded on inverse Faraday rotation in a thin film of yttrium iron garnet.
The measured reduction in resonant refraction by more than 25% exceeds that of conventional resummed negative-index materials.
The obtained reduction in absorption exceeds 10% within the measured frequency range, marking the highest value documented for any resonant plasmon-radiative medium.
Our findings suggest that radiative losses could offer a valuable method for improving absorption and refraction in plasmonic and magnetic materials.
The post-Newtonian (PN) approximation is an effective approach for examining gravitational interactions in systems that include compact objects.
The initial post-Newtonian approximation (1PN) of general relativity (GR) was developed by Einstein and Rosen in 1932.
Scalar-tensor theory (STT) extends general relativity (GR) by transforming the graviton into a broader scalar field, thereby introducing extra degrees of freedom in gravity.
The most general scalar-tensor theory (STT) action that adheres to the principles of general covariance and single-scalar-field symmetry is known as the Horndeski action.

In 1981, Deffayet and colleagues discovered a new category of scalar-tensor theories termed scalar-tensor theories with non-minimal coupling (STT[NGC]). These theories are distinct from conventional scalar-tensor theories due to the unique nature of their coupling function.

In the first approximation using the standard post-Newtonian (PN) parameter (ε = GM/(rc^2)), where M represents the mass and r denotes the distance of the system, and G is the gravitational constant, the equations of motion for a two-body system in general scalar-tensor theories (STT[NGC]) differ from those in general relativity (GR) only at the 2.5PN order. Additionally, the self-coupling of the scalar field contributes at the 1.5PN order.

In 2015, Brax et al. demonstrated that a specific variant of scalar-tensor theory known as scalar-tensor-relativistic theory (STR) serves as an effective approximation to general scalar-tensor theory in a wide range of spherically symmetric solutions, referred to as nearly solutions.

At zeroth order for the standard PN parameter, the equation of motion for a nearly spherically symmetric system in special relativity is fourth order and simplifies to the traditional Emden equation. The solutions to this equation correspond to exact scalar-Gauss-Bonnet black holes with a finite horizon.
In this letter, we examine the slow motion of particles in the vicinity of black holes and compare the resulting scalar-Gauss-Bonnet Hamiltonians with those derived from General Relativity.

Our findings indicate that: i) at the 1.5PN and 2PN levels, the initial terms in the potential and precession Hamiltonians of STR differ from those in GR due to the presence of scalar and Gauss-Bonnet topological invariants; ii) the 1PN components in the potential and precession Hamiltonians of STR are directly proportional to the square of the absolute value of the determinant of the spatial metric.
From this point forward, these invariants disappear within black holes in the context of Einstein's gravity.
In summary, we have derived the 2PN approximation for scalar-Gauss-Bonnet theories of gravity.
The generation interval (GI) refers to the duration between an individual’s infectious period and the point at which they become contagious once more.
Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, a decline in the GI has been observed in various countries, suggesting that the virus may stay viable within the population for a reduced duration.

This may facilitate a faster spread of the virus within the population or create greater uncertainty regarding when a person is contagious. This uncertainty could undermine vaccination efforts and other mitigation strategies that rely on accurately timing the infection.
To comprehend this phenomenon, we examine data on COVID-19 cases from Australia, Brazil, Italy, and the United States.
Our observations indicate that fluctuations in GI occur over time, closely aligning with the trends in cumulative cases.
This enabled us to develop a GI model that accurately reflects the observed time series.
We observe that fluctuations in GI are positively associated with changes in cumulative cases, both worldwide and over annual periods, suggesting that the reduction in GI is a global trend.
Our results suggest that real-time monitoring of COVID-19 gastrointestinal symptoms can enhance public health authorities' understanding of the pandemic and improve their response strategies.
A technique was introduced for ascertaining the electronic structure of individual dopant atoms in silicon carbide through the use of scanning probe microscopy.
Due to the differing lattice structures of dopant atoms compared to the host semiconductor, they present unique opportunities for exploring quantum systems at low temperatures.
In this study, we illustrate the application of an electrically tunable scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to locally alter the electronic structure of a single silicon carbide (SiC) atom.
Applying a rapid voltage pulse alters the electronic structure of the donor atom, resulting in a noticeable change in the dI/dV spectrum obtained with the STM.

This method would facilitate the electrical detection and manipulation of individual dopants in silicon carbide, opening new avenues for exploring quantum states in nanoscale devices and creating atomic-scale sensors with unique characteristics.

The ability to manipulate and analyze individual dopants in silicon carbide (4H-SiC) presents a thrilling opportunity to customize nanoscale devices, enabling them to exhibit unique quantum characteristics.
Research has demonstrated that a single dopant atom can serve as a valuable means to explore a quantum system at low temperatures.

For instance, the phosphorus atom is a thoroughly researched donor atom that has been utilized to showcase the spin of an individual electron and to explore electron quantum tunneling within this context.

Despite advances in technology, investigating the electronic structure of an individual dopant atom in real time and with high spatial resolution has continued to pose a substantial experimental challenge.
In this study, we utilize a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to locally alter the electronic structure of a single atom of 4H-SiC.
The alteration of the electronic structure in a single atom enables the electrical detection and manipulation of individual dopants within silicon carbide.
For instance, we utilize rapid voltage pulses in the STM to induce localized changes in the electronic structure of an individual donor atom.
A notable characteristic in the dI/dV spectrum appears when the electronic structure of the donor atom is altered.
We analyze how the alteration of the donor atom's electronic structure affects the dI/dV spectrum.

This method enables the electrical detection and manipulation of individual dopants in silicon carbide, opening avenues for exploring quantum states in nanoscale devices and advancing the creation of atomic-scale sensors with these innovative characteristics.

A growing network is a broad model where the nodes can exist in multiple states, such as "alive" or "dead." These nodes can be activated (or "arrive") and join the network based on a specific scheduling rule.
In this model, nodes can possess a variable out-degree that may fluctuate over time.
In this model, we examine the maximum in-degree that a network can accommodate when its out-degree is fixed at one, with nodes arriving according to a Poisson process.

It has been demonstrated that the maximum in-degree is one if and only if the out-degree is two. Conversely, the in-degree can be two only if the out-degree is one and the in-degree distribution is restricted to delta_0.
In other terms, the highest in-degree is constrained by both the arrival process and the out-degree of the network.
In this paper, we consider a scenario where nodes are introduced following a Poisson process, and each node has an out-degree of one in the network.
We investigate the highest possible in-degree that can be accommodated, considering that the in-degree is constrained by both the out-degree of the network and the nature of the arrival process.

It has been demonstrated that a maximum in-degree of one occurs if and only if the out-degree is two. Conversely, a maximum in-degree of two happens only when the out-degree is one and the in-degree distribution is delta_0.
It remains an unresolved question to ascertain the maximum in-degree associated with various out-degree distributions and different arrival processes.
Non-coding DNA (ncDNA) serves a purpose far beyond being labeled as mere "junk" DNA.

Comprehensive analyses of complete genomes have gathered substantial evidence demonstrating that non-coding DNA (ncDNA) sequences play a variety of critical roles within the cell. These functions range from encoding transcriptional regulatory elements and small RNAs to creating secondary structures that influence gene expression and, in some cases, even coding for entire proteins.
Significantly, two recent high-throughput RNA sequencing studies have demonstrated that as much as 98% of eukaryotic genomes are transcribed into non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs).

Although the functions of many non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) are still unclear, a growing body of evidence indicates that these molecules play essential roles within gene regulatory networks that are important for development, cell differentiation, and various other processes in living organisms.

Unlike well-known protein-coding genes, which tend to be conserved and infrequently mutated, non-coding DNA (ncDNA) sequences exhibit varying levels of variability among different species, RNA transcripts, and individual organisms.

A recent extensive analysis of whole-genome sequences from 1,201 human individuals has revealed that noncoding DNA sequences are evolving at significantly faster rates than coding sequences. This finding underscores the crucial role of noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) in facilitating rapid evolution.

Notably, a detailed examination of different types of sequence variations revealed that the majority of substitutions resulting in amino acid changes in protein-coding sequences were influenced by non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs). This highlights the significant role of ncRNAs in facilitating rapid evolution and adaptation.

During this presentation, we will explore the latest discoveries regarding the intriguing features of noncoding sequences and consider how these insights could enhance our understanding of both evolution and human health.
In this paper, we investigate simple shear flows in inelastic Maxwell models, characterized by pairwise linear interactions among the material particles.
Specifically, we will examine the case of constant shear stress.
By applying Chapman-Enskog analysis, we derive a set of nonlinear differential equations tailored for the particular distribution functions of the model.
In a one-dimensional model, we detect dynamic instability manifested as periodic density waves and compute the growth rate.
In the context of a two-dimensional model, we demonstrate that the Navier-Stokes equation is recovered when considering the limits of large time and large length scales.

An innovative method for spectral imaging based on stereoscopic vision.
We have created a hybrid differential stereoscopic (HDS) system that utilizes structured light and features two synchronized broadband optical filter liquid crystal displays (LCDs).
We utilize this system in a spectral imaging method that employs white light to determine the spatial temperature distribution of a scene.
The method we introduce integrates the high spectral resolution of multi-bandpass filter spectrography with the expansive field of view and superior spatial resolution offered by structured light.
We conduct experiments that show HDS can measure temperature differences as small as 1 degree over a 200-meter field of view with sub-millimeter precision.
Our research indicates that with further processing, this narrowband HDS system can detect temperature variations as slight as 1/1000 of a degree over a 200-meter field of view.

This method addresses many of the shortcomings found in earlier narrowband HDS systems, including the one developed by Pollefeys et al., which relies on a single optical filter, and the system created by Huang et al., which employs advanced filter spectrography but is limited to a 30-meter field of view.
We believe this work introduces an innovative approach to narrowband HDS, which is likely to make a substantial impact on various scientific and commercial spectral imaging applications.

A key feature of the pion, which is the lightest hadron, is its radius.
Measuring the radius would provide insights into our comprehension of the pion's quantum fluctuations and the characteristics of the strong interaction.

A recent suggestion for a tangible realization of the quantum NOT gate
[1] has the potential to facilitate scalable quantum computing through the use of superconducting qubits, thereby paving the way for the development of a large-scale quantum computer.

In this study, we demonstrate that the reliability of this physical implementation of the quantum NOT gate is fundamentally constrained by dissipation, which is linked to the maintenance of the von Neumann entropy of the quantum system throughout its dynamic processes.

Specifically, we discovered that the infidelity of the quantum NOT gate in this implementation, caused by entropy accumulation, was limited to less than 0.067 over the timescales necessary for quantum computation. This represents a significant improvement over other proposed physical methods for quantum computing.
This analysis establishes a new standard for precision in quantum computing, which can only be surpassed by methods that utilize error suppression through active control.
M. S. Allman and colleagues discuss the implementation of the Quantum NOT Gate for superconducting qubits in their paper, arXiv:1809.07413 (2018).

*ACTIVE CONTROL* was employed to mitigate the buildup of entropy in our physical implementation of the quantum NOT gate, thereby achieving an error rate of less than 0.067 over the timescales necessary for quantum computation.
Deep field surveys have identified a substantial number of galaxies exhibiting luminosities that greatly surpass their estimated star formation rates.
These Hyper-Luminous Infrared Galaxies (HyLIRGs) are particularly interesting candidates for studying galaxy evolution in extreme environments.
In this paper, we examine six HyLIRGs that have accessible X-ray data obtained from the XMM-Newton observatory.

This group consists of four E+A (post-starburst) galaxies: IRAS F09230–Mo1, IRAS F00183–7 Jam1, IRAS F00397–7537, and ClG J2218.1+0052, along with two late-type HyLIRGs: IRAS F00183–7 Jam2 and ClG J2218.1-0053.

All of the objects, except for IRAS F09230–Mo1, exhibit starburst-driven winds that were clearly observed in X-rays. However, none show increased absorption, indicating that the HyLIRG phenomenon might result from intense gas-rich mergers.
In 1996, Comet Hale-Bopp made a stunning appearance as it visited Earth.
In the early morning twilight for several weeks, it was visible to the public and media, sparking significant interest and prompting numerous studies across various wavelengths.
In this paper, we share the findings from our mid-infrared study of Hale-Bopp.
In April, May, and June of 1996, we conducted observations of Hale-Bopp at both the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) and the Copernicus Space Observatory.
These data provide evidence of polarized light from Hale-Bopp for the first time.
Our findings indicate that Hale-Bopp consists of many slender, elongated ice grains that are oriented almost perpendicular to both the comet's orbital plane and its parent nucleus.
These findings could be clarified by considering that the uneven expulsion of material from Hale-Bopp's nucleus might have been responsible for the comet's rotation and orbital angular momentum.
We additionally analyze the dust coma of Hale-Bopp and determine its minimum orbit intersection distance (MOID).
Our observations revealed that the MOID of Hale-Bopp was around 3.2 Earth radii, which closely corresponds to the size of the observed coma.
We explore the significance of our findings for the theories surrounding the formation of Hale-Bopp and its parent nucleus, as well as for upcoming cometary missions.

We share the findings from a spectral index distribution (SIND) analysis conducted on a comprehensive, flux-rescaled sample of gamma-ray blazars identified by the Energetic Gamma Ray Experiment Telescope (EGRET) aboard NASA's Compton Gamma-Ray Observatory.
We additionally provide an initial SIND analysis of the nearly simultaneous 3EG sample.
In contrast to most gamma-ray telescopes, EGRET identified nearly all blazars as highly polarized gamma rays, with almost all showing significant variability across a wide range of timescales.
Blazars are generally considered the most luminous type of gamma-ray sources, and their spectra typically conform to a straightforward power law with a photon index of approximately 2.2.

We conduct the inaugural SIND analysis on high-energy gamma-ray blazars by utilizing a fully flux-rescaled sample derived from the third EGRET catalog. Our findings reveal that the SIND of EGRET blazars aligns with a one-dimensional truncated power law featuring an exponential cutoff.
The blazar SIND exhibits a slope of about -2.2 at high energies (E > 100 MeV), whereas the slope at lower energies is a bit less steep.
The high-energy index resembles that of the low-energy gamma-ray flux, but it comes with significant error bars.
We also provide an initial SIND analysis of the 3EG data; however, the limited number of sources and incomplete sampling of the EGRET band constrain the conclusions we can make.
The EGRET blazar SIND could be crucial for unraveling the mechanisms behind high-energy emissions in these objects and their relationship with particles in extragalactic magnetic fields.
The phenomenon known as 'dark energy' was thought to be the cause of the universe's recent accelerated expansion.
Independent observations of this phenomenon have only emerged since the late 2000s, leading to considerable debate over when exactly the universe began its acceleration.
In this study, we utilize a variety of datasets to assess the timing of the shift from deceleration to acceleration.
Our analysis reveals that although there is considerable consensus regarding the average transition time, the accuracy of this determination varies significantly based on the dataset selected.

Our research suggests that cosmologists might have exaggerated the uncertainty regarding the timing of the transition, and we are considering how this could affect the planning of upcoming dark energy surveys.
The acceleration of cosmic expansion was first observed in the late 2000s, and its underlying cause has since become a focus of rigorous research.
Indirect evidence for this phenomenon, derived from measurements of cosmological parameters, has only emerged in the past ten years.
As a result, the exact moment when the expansion began to accelerate has been a subject of discussion and debate.

In this study, we address this question by analyzing a variety of datasets. Our findings reveal that although there is strong consistency regarding the average transition time, the accuracy of this measurement is significantly influenced by the selected dataset.
Our research suggests that cosmologists have exaggerated the uncertainty regarding the timing of the transition, and this has implications for the planning of upcoming dark energy surveys.

Our findings were derived from recent observations of the cosmic microwave background (CMB), which is the residual radiation from the Big Bang. We also considered the lensing of background light by large-scale structures and direct measurements of the universe's expansion rate through distant supernovae.
Our analysis indicates that the data most strongly suggest the transition from deceleration to acceleration occurs between z = 0.5 and z = 0.0.

The accuracy of this determination is significantly influenced by the dataset utilized. Our calculations are founded on the following datasets: z = 0.0 - 0.5 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.5), z = 0.0 - 0.2 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.2), and z = 0.0 - 0.01 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.01).

The 74MHz system was implemented at the Very Large Array (VLA) in 2012 and has since identified hundreds of radio sources, including pulsars, planets, and synchrotron radiation generated within our galaxy.
The 74MHz system consisted of 24 separate channels, each 225kHz wide, and spans a total frequency range of 11.2 to 74.1MHz.
The entire band was split into two polarizations, each 75.6 MHz wide, which were Nyquist-sampled at a rate of 1.2875 MHz.
Each baseband channel has a width of 25.6 kHz, which results in a velocity resolution of 22.1 km/s and a temperature sensitivity of -82.6 dBm for a single beam.
The 74MHz system has been employed to measure redshifts in luminous galaxies as high as 7.5, explore the Epoch of Reionization, and perform experiments related to gravitational waves.
The data from the 74MHz system was publicly released via the F.C. Williams antenna record.

In this study, we investigate the potential insights that can be gained from analyzing the distribution of the largest fragment in a zirconium-rich, iron-rich sample of 304 stainless steel, employing artificial intelligence methods.

The objective is to determine whether the distribution of the largest fragment, referred to as the "vital trace," can serve as a fingerprint for identifying the sample's origin and whether it provides insights into the processes involved in its formation.

We implement a supervised machine learning algorithm that classifies data into three categories: "iron-rich," "zirconium-rich," and "304 stainless steel." The model uses the elemental concentrations of 26 elements as features, while the vital trace distribution serves as the target variable.

We discovered that the algorithm successfully learned to distinguish between the classes and produced distinct predictions for each of the three categories, achieving over 70% accuracy using just 10% of the training samples.

We implemented a comparable algorithm, utilizing histological images of burns as input, and discovered that it effectively distinguished between "304 stainless steel" and "fire" samples, even with just 3 burn images for training.
This indicates that the distribution of vital traces may provide insights into the processes that took place prior to the material's formation.

We believe this work serves as a proof of concept, demonstrating that the distribution of the largest fragment—potentially lost during the material manufacturing process—can provide valuable information for identifying the processes that occurred prior to the material's formation.
Recent developments in thin film fabrication technologies have sparked a resurgence of interest in the exploration of magnetic thin films.

This arises from the presence of both ferromagnetic layers and layers that interact strongly through the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yoshida (RKKY) mechanism in sub-micron thin films, resulting in new magnetic ground states and intricate phase diagrams.
In this study, we provide a magnetic characterization of Co/Pt multilayer thin films that were synthesized through selective area epitaxy.
Our x-ray magnetic circular dichroism measurements in the remanent state indicate that a nanometer-scale uncompensated magnetic region remains at low temperatures.
We examined our results in relation to the current theoretical frameworks pertaining to thin film magnetic phase diagrams.

"Nature of Phase Transition in Magnetic Thin Films" Recent developments in thin film fabrication technology have sparked a resurgence of interest in the exploration of magnetic thin films.

This occurs because of the simultaneous presence of ferromagnetic layers and layers with strong Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yoshida (RKKY) interactions in sub-micron thin films, resulting in innovative magnetic ground states and intricate phase diagrams.
In this study, we provide a magnetic characterization of Co/Pt multilayer thin films that were synthesized through selective area epitaxy.
Our x-ray magnetic circular dichroism measurements in the remanent state indicate that a nanometer-scale uncompensated magnetic region remains at low temperatures.
We analyzed our findings in relation to the current theoretical frameworks of thin film magnetic phase diagrams.
In the initial section of this paper, we present a novel algorithm designed to address the advection-diffusion equation with dynamic boundaries, also known as free boundaries.
The algorithm employs a discrete ordinates method, utilizing a finite difference technique for discretizing both spatial and velocity dimensions.
This approach is precise when the boundaries are either periodic or moved with a constant linear velocity.
We demonstrate that it remains consistent when the advection speed is linearly interpolated between the center of the cell and its boundary.
In practice, this method is effective as long as the advection speed isn't excessively high and the spatial resolution is reasonably good.
As an illustration of its application, we model the growth of solids within a viscous accretion disk.
We evaluate our algorithm using analytical solutions of the diffusion-advection equation and demonstrate that our findings align with the anticipated analytical results.
We subsequently apply our algorithm to investigate the evolution of solids within a viscous accretion disk, exploring different sets of initial conditions.
In every instance, solids cannot approach the central star within a timespan of ten thousand years.
In the second section, we examine how solids influence the evolution of dust within the disk.
Solids produce a size distribution that is different from that of dust grains.
In particular, solids often produce a substantial quantity of sub-micron sized particles.
The specific form of this size distribution is influenced by the size and composition of the solid materials.
In this section, we introduce a number of straightforward models designed to explore how solids affect the evolution of dust.
We demonstrate that solids of a specific size and composition lead to varying effects on the dust size distribution.

Ultimately, we demonstrate that the precise shape of the size distribution has minimal impact on dust evolution throughout most of the disk. After approximately one million years, only large grains remain, and the evolution is entirely governed by dust settling and radial drift.
We conclude that solids cannot approach the central star within a ten-thousand-year timeframe; however, they play a significant role in the evolution of dust.
