The Higher Order Schwarzian Derivative (HOSD) was introduced, along with its applications for analyzing chaotic behavior and a novel invariant sufficient condition for chaos.
First, we will provide the definition of HOSD along with a discussion of its properties.
The subsequent analysis examines the connection between HOSD and asymptotic stability.
The use of HOSD to identify sufficient conditions for chaos was presented.
Furthermore, a novel invariant sufficient condition for chaos has been introduced.
Finally, several examples are provided to illustrate the validity of the findings.
The Higher Order Schwarzian Derivative (HOSD) has been introduced, along with its applications in analyzing chaotic behavior and a novel invariant sufficient condition for chaos.
Initially, we will define HOSD and outline several of its properties.
The subsequent analysis focuses on the connection between HOSD and asymptotic stability.
The use of HOSD to identify sufficient conditions for chaos is presented.
In addition, a new sufficient invariant condition for chaos has been introduced.
Ultimately, several examples were provided to illustrate the validity of the findings.
Cool stars significantly influence the dynamics of galaxies by transferring energy and material from the core.
Nevertheless, their impact reaches well beyond their host galaxy, as they can influence the structure of the interstellar medium (ISM) and even the galactic halo through feedback mechanisms.
We present new optical and ALMA observations of a unique cool star, designated HK loops, located in the metal-rich circumnuclear disk of the spiral galaxy M83.
This star is situated close to the galactic center, just a few kiloparsecs away from the supermassive black hole, and it may be gaining mass through accretion.

We announce the likely occurrence of a gas ejection event, accompanied by the observation of broad molecular and atomic hydrogen lines. This marks the first detection of its kind in a cool star, apart from the Sun.
We also observe a flow in the dusty plasma emanating from this star, providing additional evidence of the intricate interaction between the star and its surroundings.
We explore the possible ramifications of this discovery for our comprehension of cool star feedback in extreme conditions and its relationship to the evolution of galaxies.
A likely explanation for the narrow emission lines observed in Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) is the presence of gas moving towards the nucleus, commonly described as a "receding" gas supply.

Through the simultaneous spectral modeling of gas dynamics and ionization, we demonstrate that among a group of 65 active galactic nuclei (AGN) with available optical spectroscopy and X-shooting data, most galaxies exhibit double-sinusoidal receding profiles characterized by two distinct minima: one signifying motion away from the nucleus and the other indicating motion towards it.

The data indicate that the distribution of accretion rates onto supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGN) host galaxies might not adhere to a single decreasing function; instead, it may exhibit a double-peaked distribution.

The underlying physical mechanism that might lead to this distribution is still unclear; however, the observed bimodality suggests that "two-mode" feedback could play a significant role in the coevolution of AGNs and their host galaxies.

The near-ultraviolet and optical spectra of ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) are typically accurately represented by continuum models, which may include a straightforward multicolor blackbody (MBB) or more intricate components like an accretion disk combined with blackbody emission.

By employing either parametric models, such as the accretion disk spectrum from the Cambridge Accretion Code, or non-parametric models like cubic splines, it is possible to independently determine the apparent radius of the emission region in relation to the gravitational potential of the black hole.
We show that the estimated Eddington ratios and the temperature of the MBB continuum are highly sensitive to the assumed spectral shape for a specific black hole mass and distance.

Utilizing a spherical model, like relativistic disk inverse Compton scattering, and considering a high-spin black hole (with a spin parameter of $a$=0.95) having a mass of 1.4 M⊙ for ESO243-49 HLX, we demonstrate that the estimated Eddington ratio would be halved if the spectrum is modeled as a modified blackbody (MBB) instead of a combined disk and blackbody (disk+BB) spectrum. Furthermore, if we assume a disk+BB spectrum with an apparent temperature of kT = 0.15 keV instead of 0.6 keV, the Eddington ratio would decrease by a factor of five. Additionally, we reveal that for the same black hole mass and spectrum, the estimated temperature of the MBB continuum varies significantly depending on whether the spectrum is a MBB with kT = 0.15 keV or a disk+BB spectrum with kT = 0.6 keV.

These variations affect the classification of ULXs with similar near-infrared emissions, determining whether their characteristics are primarily influenced by a high-spin black hole or by an advection-dominated accretion flow.
We explore the implications for interpreting ULX spectra and propose observational tests that could aid in distinguishing between various models of the ULX continuum emission.

Recent hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy mergers indicate that a narrow, deep central channel may develop in the midplane of the merger remnant, aligned with the direction of gas inflow, facilitating the transport of substantial amounts of gas to the central kiloparsec.

This gas can provide energy to the central massive black hole (MBH), resulting in accelerated growth and a distinctive phase of high luminosity known as the active galactic nucleus (AGN) phase, often referred to as the “quasar” phase.
Further nuclear starbursts can enhance the circumnuclear gas and contribute to the observed Seyfert activity.

In this Letter, we model the inspiraling of two supermassive black holes (MBHs), with masses scaled from the observed dimensions of the central channel. Our simulations indicate that within less than 1 Gyr, the less massive black hole will merge with the more massive one, resulting in a growing remnant of approximately 10^8 solar masses. This remnant is more likely to be an active galactic nucleus bulge rather than a Schwarzschild black hole.
Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) typically originate from material stripped away from other galaxies during high-velocity encounters.
TDGs offer a compelling opportunity to test gravitational theories in high-dispersion environments, as they emerge at high velocities where the effects of gravity are minimal.
MOND does not offer a robust test, and the discrepancies with observations could indicate that it does not accurately represent the gravitational force in low-acceleration conditions.
As a result, altering MOND presents a compelling option that might address the discrepancies between MOND predictions and the observed behavior of tidal TDGs.

We demonstrate through N-body simulations that alterations to MOND, which incorporate a mass-dependent acceleration scale defined by g0(r) ~ r-a0 (with a0 as a constant), can effectively account for the dynamics of tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs).
The interpolating function fs(R) = (a0/r)² aligns well with the rotation curves of dark matter halos, indicating that it might also emerge naturally from a modification of MOND.

We utilize this interpolating function for Tidal Dwarf Galaxies (TDGs) and demonstrate that it accurately captures the scaling of their internal dynamics in relation to galaxy mass, rotational velocity, and orbital orientation, all while being independent of a0.
These findings indicate that the discrepancy noted between MOND and the dynamics of tidal dwarf galaxies may be resolved through modifications to MOND that bridge the strong and weak gravity regimes.
A rotating stratified flow, like that found in a planetary boundary layer, incorporates both vortical and wave modes.

We conduct a numerical simulation of a statistically uniform, rotating stratified flow characterized by significant stochastic variations in rotation, temperature, and density, while utilizing double periodic boundary conditions in the horizontal directions.
The flow becomes turbulent over time, influenced by the initial conditions.
We calculate time-averaged flow statistics, energy spectra, and both kinetic and potential enstrophies.

Potential enstrophy is primarily concentrated at larger scales and appears to diminish according to an infrared logarithmic law, whereas kinetic enstrophy is focused on smaller scales and appears to undergo a cascading process.
The primary large-scale forcing predominantly consists of vortical modes, exhibiting a wide-ranging distribution of energy throughout the flow.

Over time, a more localized energy distribution emerges, characterized by a significant portion of energy being concentrated at smaller scales, following the principles of the cascaded spectral model.
The dynamic range is too extensive to be completely represented through a direct numerical simulation using a fine grid spacing.
This is the inaugural direct numerical simulation of a statistically uniform rotating stratified flow, which reveals the presence of both vortical and wave modes.
It also uncovers the spatial and temporal scales of dynamic range and cascade range, offering suggestions for future research directions.

In the field of dynamical systems theory, the Generalized Alignment Index (GALI) serves as a novel dynamical metric for assessing local numerical order and is capable of identifying even subtle interactions among chaotic trajectories.
In this study, we explore the fundamental properties of GALI, including its definition, its stability under coordinate transformations, and its behavior during saturation.
We will also explore its key geometric features, such as its singularities and limit sets.

We demonstrate the various features and applications of GALI through several examples. These include calculating the geometrical factors that influence the stability of various types of periodic orbits, estimating the thresholds for global instability in dynamical systems, and analyzing the pathways to separatrices in perturbed homoclinic and homoclinic bifurcations.
We additionally utilize GALI to identify multiple synchronization, providing illustrative examples, and to examine the stability of synchronous states in coupled maps of varying dimensions.
Lattices have found extensive application across a range of fields, such as computer science, statistics, and social sciences, as a means to more accurately depict the underlying structures.

For instance, the protein structure is conceptualized as a three-dimensional lattice, where each point in the lattice represents a specific protein atom. The distance between any two atoms reflects the shortest path through the chemical bonds and other interactions that connect them within the protein structure.

In this context, the protein structure can be represented as a Boolean lattice, with each point in the lattice assigned a value of either "1" or "0." This indicates the presence or absence of a chemical bond between the atoms in question.
A comparable lattice concept has also been utilized in social sciences to represent social connections, distinguishing between close friends and more distant acquaintances.

Thus, social networks can be regarded as a specific type of graph, where the vertices symbolize individuals and the edges denote the strength of the connections between them. This structure can also be effectively represented using Boolean lattices.

By examining graph structures across various applications in a lattice-aware way, we can uncover hidden patterns and structures that may have gone unnoticed due to the limitations of current modeling techniques.
The 8 micron luminosity function (LF) of the local galaxy was obtained from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) DR7 data, utilizing the observations in the U, g, r, i, and z bands.
We compute the galaxy number counts in bins of 0.5 dex width based on i band apparent magnitude, Kron magnitude, and Petrosian radius R50.
The luminosity function is described by a double Schechter function model.
We utilize a maximum likelihood method to identify the optimal fitting parameters and discover strong evidence of curvature in the galaxy number counts.

Through simulations, we investigate the impacts of shot noise, edge effects, and survey limits on our LF results and determine that these factors do not considerably influence our assessments of the double Schechter function parameters.
By applying our optimized Schechter function, we estimate the number of galaxies across various ranges of apparent magnitude.

We compared our findings with published values from the SDSS Ninth Data Release and observed generally good agreement. However, our results suggest some indications of higher normalizations at brighter apparent magnitudes and a lower characteristic magnitude.
Utilizing our optimal Schechter function, we compute the absolute i-band magnitudes of the sample galaxies and analyze these results in comparison to stellar population synthesis models.
We discover that the characteristic luminosity of the galaxies in our sample aligns with passively evolving stellar populations that formed recently at redshifts around z~2.
Social influence is ever-present in our daily lives, affecting a broad range of decisions, from our everyday routines to significant strategic choices like selecting an employer.
Although social influence is widespread, most individuals struggle to articulate the strategies for resisting its pressure.

In this paper, we examine a general decision-making scenario where an agent encounters several alternatives that are influenced by the agent's own selections. Each alternative is associated with a social influencer who has a specific preference for one of the options.
The agent aims to choose an option that aligns with its preferences while also maximizing its own benefits.
We delineate the structure of this generic problem and present the necessary and sufficient criteria for an option to be considered the top choice of the social influencer.
Based on this characterization, we propose an algorithm for the agent to follow that guarantees the maximization of its expected utility.

Ultimately, we showcase how our framework can be applied to real-world decision-making scenarios influenced by social factors. This includes choosing a restaurant based on a friend’s recommendation and selecting a college by considering admission criteria and SAT scores.
Doubly-charged scalars have been suggested as potential candidates for dark matter and as an explanation for the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon.
These particles can also be generated at colliders, and if they decay into standard model (SM) particles, they may produce signatures characterized by large multi-lepton invariant masses.

In this paper, we demonstrate that the data from LHC Run II regarding the production of pairs of doubly-charged scalars can be utilized to impose the most stringent direct collider constraints to date on the parameter space of this model.

We examine a particular two-Higgs-doublet model (2HDM) as a case study, demonstrating that after accounting for the influences of oblique electroweak corrections, this model is rendered less favored in light of the observed Higgs signal strengths.
We subsequently revise our earlier analysis of this model by incorporating constraints from the LHC Run II data regarding multi-lepton plus MET signals.
We demonstrate that, in this scenario, 2HDM models incorporating explicit flavor symmetries align with all existing data.
In full counting statistics, the moments of the transferred charge differ from those of a Gaussian distribution when the detector exhibits finite resistance.
The third cumulant is positive for all values of the counting field when the resistance of the environment exceeds a specific threshold.
In this instance, for an extended period before the quantum mechanical system attains its steady state, its dynamics resemble those of an inverted harmonic oscillator.

We conduct experimental research on the counting statistics of charge transfer in a quantum point contact (QPC), analyzing how it varies with the environmental resistance R. By imposing an appropriate voltage bias on the external environment, we are able to modify its impedance, which in turn affects the threshold for non-Gaussian behavior.
For sufficiently small resistance, we find that the third cumulant remains positive.

This finding aligns quantitatively with the predictions of a rate equation model that utilizes a comprehensive quantum framework for the dissipative quantum point contact (QPC), applicable for both negative and positive values of the counting field.

Our research offers the first direct experimental examination of the complete counting statistics of a microscopic quantum system that is interfaced with an external system exhibiting arbitrary spectral density.

Grazing-incidence X-ray telescopes (GIXTs) are engineered to capture X-ray signals from space that are emitted almost perpendicular to the optical aperture. This design helps to reduce optical throughput and prevents optical distortions.
As a result, GIXTs had to be fitted with highly compact grazing-incidence mirrors to comply with the satellite's volume and weight limitations.

As a result, these mirrors are composed of thin layers of highly dense materials, typically gold or silver, which makes them particularly susceptible to electron contamination. This refers to the low-energy electrons that may exist within the satellite's vicinity and could be emitted by the modules connected to the telescope.

We introduce a model designed to assess the electron contamination within the satellite volume, utilizing measurements of the X-ray signals captured by the telescope. This model is then applied to analyze the decrease in electron contamination caused by the inclusion of a low-voltage power unit (LVPU) attached to the satellite.
We demonstrate that this degradation can exceed several tens of percent and that it correlates with the intensity of the X-ray signal incident on the satellite.
Nanodevices generally do not have classical counterparts when it comes to the transfer of heat and charge.
However, some have suggested that the fluctuation theorem could be relevant to these cases.

We demonstrate that this is actually false.

We examine the Jarzynski equality in the context of nanodevices [3, 4] and show that it does not hold for a straightforward system comprised of two coupled Langevin equations featuring a bistable potential.
The typical derivation of the Jarzynski equality, which relies on the reversibility of Hamiltonian dynamics, is not applicable in this scenario.
Consequently, there are speculations that the fluctuation theorem may not be applicable to nanodevices [5].
We demonstrate that this is not true and present a revised fluctuation relation, which we confirm through direct numerical integration of the complete dynamics of the nanodevice.
In references [1, 2], Nataf and Vulpiani suggested that the fluctuation theorem could be relevant to Brownian motors.
They demonstrated that the energy dynamics during a transient phase of a Nosè-Hoover oscillator, which serves as a classic model for a Brownian motor, conform to the Jarzynski equality.
It has since been demonstrated that the Nosè-Hoover oscillator is Hamiltonian and that the Jarzynski equality is valid [3, 4].
Consequently, it has been determined that the assertion regarding the applicability of the fluctuation theorem to Brownian motors is inaccurate.
Our research expands the list of systems for which the Jarzynski equality is invalid by including nanodevices.

We want to highlight that the Jarzynski equality is not necessary for the fluctuation theorem to be applicable. In fact, our findings demonstrate that an even broader modified fluctuation relation is valid for the system we are examining.

We examine the fluctuation theorem applicable to nanodevices, specifically focusing on the relationship between the probability distributions of the work performed on the system and the free energy difference between two stable states.

Debris disks are what remain from protoplanetary disks, the early formations from which planets develop.
Numerous debris disks display an unexpected consistency in their dust characteristics and brightness, implying that planet formation could happen swiftly, within a period of less than 1,000 years.

Nevertheless, there is strong evidence indicating that planetesimals continue to form in numerous debris disks. This includes dynamic evidence for the presence of planet-mass bodies and collision-related evidence for the swift creation of sizable planetesimals.
The collisional interactions among planetesimals contribute to the accumulation of material in debris disks, potentially resulting in detectable characteristics like infrared excesses and gaps.
The beginning of this collisional evolution is postponed due to the formation of embryo bodies.

I provide a summary of the observational constraints regarding embedded planet-mass objects in various debris disk systems, introduce new dynamical limits on their potential existence, and argue that the dynamical evidence supporting the presence of planet-mass bodies is strong.

I provide an overview of the limitations on the collisional evolution of planetesimals resulting from collisions with larger bodies, outlining the timeframe for planetesimal growth. Additionally, I explore the implications of these limitations for the formation of short-lived planets.
I believe that the simultaneous formation of planetesimals and embryos in debris disks is a well-supported conclusion, and it seems that an explanation for their coexistence was probably necessary.
This study conducts a sensitivity analysis of the MICS Asia Phase II Daily Gridded Data products in relation to the Aerosol Module, focusing on both drought and non-drought seasons.
The analysis suggests that the MICS Asia Phase II Aerosol product is generally resilient to variations in Aerosol optical depth across both seasons.
Nonetheless, several channels were discovered to be notably influenced by the selection of AOD inputs.
These channels relate to the Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) observed by IASI in Southern India, as well as the AOD recorded by MISR over the Eastern Pacific Ocean.
The analysis further reveals that the MICS Asia Phase II AOD product demonstrates greater sensitivity to AOD values calculated using the correlated thinNRG and DRF models during the drought season.
This may result from the influence of Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) in the Indian region during the drought season, which is not accurately represented by the correlated models.

Regarding AOD sources, the analysis indicates that overlooking the AOD contributions from boundary layer and molecular species could have a substantial effect on the MICS Asia Phase II AOD product during the drought season.
This document is a result of the Technical Internal Review for MICS Asia Phase II.
Comptonization is frequently used to elucidate the intricate spectra of accreting compact objects, including X-ray binaries and black hole binaries.

In this scenario, seed photons originating from a cold disk are upscattered by electrons in a hot plasma, resulting in a power-law component that can account for as much as 100% of the spectrum in certain systems.
In this study, we showcase broadband X-ray observations of the island state within the transient binary system IGR J1748-288, conducted using the XMM-Newton orbiting X-ray observatory.
The data indicate that the source emits radiation in the hard X-ray range, characterized by a power-law photon index of −2.3 ± 0.2.
This result stands in sharp opposition to the Wien tail of the blackbody spectrum typically seen in this state.

We thoroughly investigate the Comptonization model and demonstrate that it offers a superior representation of the broadband X-ray spectrum compared to a straightforward thermal accretion shock model.

By employing Monte Carlo simulations, we investigate the parameter space and show that incorporating relativistic Doppler shift and broadening is essential for effectively applying this model to the broadband spectra of IGR J1748-288.

In conclusion, we demonstrate that the temperature of the Comptonizing plasma is positively related to the amplitude of the kHz QPOs, reinforcing the notion that these QPOs represent a Doppler-scaled variant of the inner accretion flow.
The remarkable resolution and dynamic range of contemporary cosmological simulations have enabled the identification of several previously unknown discrete effects.

Here, we concentrate on factors that might impact the validity of the cosmological paradigm, specifically the limitations of standard algorithms in accurately tracking the behavior of dark matter particles after they become increasingly confined within collapsed structures.

Our research reveals that these "shell-crossing" events cause significant shifts in the spatial arrangement of dark matter particles, displacing them by several tens of kiloparsecs. These displacements are persistent and take hundreds of Hubble times to restore to their original state.

These so-called "discreteness effects" could pose a major challenge to employing dark matter as a cosmological tool, possibly resulting in biases on scales that are equal to or larger than those seen in current galaxy surveys.
In this accompanying paper, we measure the impact of these previously unquantified effects on current cosmological data.

The Carter constant, which acts as a proportionality factor between the spin of an inspiraling compact object and its orbital angular momentum, has been demonstrated to be critical in assessing whether a binary black hole system will form as a result of the inspiral process.

A recent study by Hinder et al. (2021) explored the significance of the Carter constant in the dynamics of black hole binary systems. The findings revealed that, for systems that are formed, the Carter constant changes over time, resulting in the spins of the binary system aligning with the orbital angular momentum.

The analysis indicates that, in specific scenarios, influenced by the strength of the black hole's quadrupolar moment and the alignment of the orbital plane, the constant varies in such a way that the spin of one black hole becomes antiparallel to the orbital angular momentum.
In this study, we build upon the previous research by thoroughly examining how the quadrupolar moment of black holes influences the evolution of the Carter constant.
Our analysis shows that for binaries exhibiting small quadrupoles, the evolution behaves qualitatively alike to that of systems without any quadrupolar moment.
However, in the case of larger quadrupoles, the evolution becomes discontinuous, leading to divergent values of the constant.

We show that this behavior can be explained using a straightforward geometric argument related to the impact parameter of the binary system. Additionally, we identify a critical value of the quadrupole moment, beyond which the evolution of the constant undergoes a significant qualitative change.
We present examples of systems exhibiting different properties where our predictions are relevant and explore the astrophysical implications of our results.
The reionization process marked the end of the universe's darkness and serves as an essential instrument for exploring its physics and astronomy.
The 21-cm emission and absorption signals reflect the neutral fraction of the intergalactic medium (IGM) and are shaped by the underlying density field structure as well as the movement of galaxies.
Observing the early stages of cosmic reionization is difficult due to their localized nature within the extensive 21-cm signal.
Correlated random walks (CRWs) serve as a statistical method for extracting small-scale information from broader signal patterns.
In this paper, we investigate how galaxy bias and non-linear coupling influence the statistics of cosmic microwave background (CMB) residuals.
We produce CRW signals using N-body simulations that explore the physics of cosmic reionization, and we find that the CRW signal is strongest when the galaxy bias is at the percent level.
By utilizing the CRW signal in conjunction with observations from the Global Epoch of Reionization Array (Glow), we can constrain the galaxy bias parameter to within 3.7% (1 sigma).

Additionally, we demonstrate that the best-fit bias diverges from the intrinsic bias, which is determined through N-body simulations. This suggests that upcoming observations at higher frequencies could provide improved constraints on the bias.
In this paper, we examine a two-stage hybrid and modular inflation process: 1.
Early hybrid inflation is driven by a gauge field that is coupled to a fundamental scalar field and its superpartner.
Of course! Please provide the paragraph you'd like me to rewrite.
Modular inflation induced by a charged scalar field interacting with gravity.

We discover that, in general, these two stages can progress sequentially, with the decay of the false vacuum during the first stage generating the curvature perturbations required for the second stage.
This provides the flexibility to select the parameters for each model while maintaining the feasibility of the next stage.
In this model, the density perturbations exhibit a flat spectrum.
This work builds upon the findings presented in the earlier paper arXiv:1908.05761.
In this paper, we explore a somewhat distinct scenario where the decay of the first-stage false vacuum does not merely generate curvature perturbations, but instead amplifies them.
This research is also connected to arXiv:1907.11961.
In this work, we examine a model that incorporates multiple inflationary stages and determine the parameter conditions necessary for these stages to successfully transition from one to another.
For the first time, a natural broadening of the iron K alpha resonance line was detected in the X-ray spectrum of NGC 3783.
The measured width of this line is considerably greater than the resolution of the instrument.
Given that the observed width is similar to the gas velocity in the Broad Line Region, it is likely that the broadening observed was caused by velocity-dependent scattering within the nucleus's disk.
This scattering might be attributed to small-scale variations in gas density or to irregularities in the spherical symmetry of the gravitational potential within the nucleus.
For the first time, the redshifted iron K alpha line and the underlying continuum were also investigated.
The shape of the continuum aligns well with the findings of earlier research.

The measured equivalent width of the line is roughly 120 eV, while its value in the rest frame is around 240 eV. The observed correlation between the equivalent width and the line's redshift suggests that the emission and fluorescence processes in the Broad Line Region are more intricate than earlier assumptions have indicated.
The variability of NGC 3783 across various time scales is also examined.
After two years of X-ray observations using Chandra, no notable fluctuations in the line flux were detected.
The variability of the equivalent width was not statistically significant even at the 2-sigma level.
Variability over extended time periods cannot be observed in the existing data.
Silicon surfaces exhibit various fascinating phenomena thanks to the significant disparity in electronegativity between silicon and oxygen.
One of the most remarkable examples is the regular stepping pattern on the (100) surface, which has been observed for over seventy years.

In contrast, the (110) surface exhibits a comparable structure characterized by a two-fold symmetry. This phenomenon was originally described in 1952 and referred to as the "densité échelonnée," or "stepped array of chains."
The (110) surface, with its intricate faceted shape, has been the focus of numerous recent studies.
In this report, we present high-resolution low-energy electron microscopy experiments that provide a comprehensive reconstruction model for vicinal (100) and (110) surfaces.

Alongside the well-documented surface step density-wave pattern, we notice that the steps and chains bend at the triple points between them, resulting in the creation of “V”-shaped steps due to facet influence.
By employing a straightforward model, we can elucidate the key characteristics of this distinctive reconstruction.
The information presented here will aid in the planning and execution of future experiments and simulations on these fascinating surfaces.
This paper focuses on the controllability of both the heat and wave equations.
We begin by introducing a set of innovative, explicit finite difference methods designed to approximate the heat and wave equations.
Next, we examine the controllability of finite difference methods by characterizing the controls as localized functions applied to the edges of the domain.

By meticulously selecting these localized functions, we can demonstrate that the precise solutions of the heat and wave equations can be controlled to any desired state in an arbitrarily small amount of time.
This outcome is valid at any positive moment, regardless of the size of the domain.
Our findings on controllability are based solely on the local characteristics of the precise solution and the spatial dynamics of the controls.
We also provide counterexamples demonstrating that our findings do not hold universally for the exact heat and wave equations.
This work is a collaboration with Marta Sanz-Soriano.
Long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) represent the most explosive events in the universe.
Nonetheless, their research is complicated by the unpredictable nature of their randomly directed beams, which makes accurate localization challenging.
Transient gamma-ray bursts with established cosmological redshifts offer a vital chance to investigate their nature.
Long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) represent the most cataclysmic explosions in the universe.
Nonetheless, their research is made challenging due to the unpredictable and randomly directed beams, which hinder accurate localization.
Transient gamma-ray bursts observed at identified cosmological redshifts offer a vital opportunity to explore the nature and structure of the universe.
Most long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) have been detected by the Swift satellite, which offers both prompt localization and a comprehensive array of multi-wavelength data.
We analyzed the spectral evolution of 57 long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) observed by Swift, all of which have established redshifts, and identified three distinctly different regimes.
The initial regime features a cooling break, which is then succeeded by a straightforward power law.
In this regime, two to four dissipation slopes were noted.
The second regime, observed in 17 bursts, is defined by an initial thermal component represented by a blackbody function or a non-thermal tail, which is then succeeded by a single power law.
In the third and final regime, observed in 30 bursts, there is no discernible spectral break, and the spectra can be accurately represented by a single power law.
The cosmological models that most accurately explain the observed burst data are curved uploads and a finite universe, showing probabilities of 68.3% and 95.7%, respectively.
This finding is unexpected because standard candle models operate under the assumption that all bursts possess identical intrinsic luminosity, leading to a consistent power law across all ranges.
This project received partial funding from a NASA Swift Award (No. 1223370) awarded to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
In recent years, the electronic properties of dry DNA have garnered significant attention because of their potential applications in electronic technologies.
The electronic characteristics of dry DNA differ considerably from those of its hydrated form.
For instance, dry DNA exhibits significantly higher conductivity and transitions to a semiconducting state at room temperature.
Grasping the electronic properties of dry DNA is crucial for its prospective uses in electronic technologies and DNA-based sensors.
Despite its significant technological relevance, the electronic structure and mechanisms of dry DNA remain incompletely understood.
In this study, we created a multiscale model for dry DNA that captures its electronic transport properties, spanning from the atomic level to the macroscopic scale.
The energy functional theory is employed to model the local structure of a segment of dry DNA.
A transport model is created using the tight-binding method to characterize the electronic transport properties of the entire length of dry DNA.

The newly developed model will encompass electronic transport behaviors ranging from the atomic level to the macroscopic level, marking a significant advancement in our understanding of the electronic structure and mechanisms of dry DNA.

An examination of quantum error correction within holographic codes indicates that the error-correcting capabilities of these codes depend on the causal structure of spacetime. However, this structure can be distorted by environmental factors and may become less discernible upon observation.

We propose a model of holographic noise that takes into account the impact of environmental interactions on the states of black hole horizons. This model reveals that, even in an error-free scenario, the retrieval of local boundary data is fundamentally influenced by an unavoidable quantum uncertainty inherent in the characterization of the horizon.
As a result, the interactions with the environment make it difficult to accurately calculate local boundary data, creating an illusion that we can rely on these expectations.

Although the specific structure of the noise model outlined here is probably not an accurate reflection of real experimental conditions, we show that this noise model creates a fundamental constraint on the precision with which local boundary data can be calculated. Furthermore, it provides a clear and intuitive explanation for numerous experimental results that have been challenging to understand in the past.

The study investigates strain localization within a shear transformation zone (STZ) model for amorphous materials.

In this model, the amorphous solid consists of particles that interact through a potential featuring a short-range repulsive core and a long-range attractive tail. This potential is subjected to shear below the glass transition temperature, Tg, which results in the formation of the amorphous solid.

During quasistatic deformation, areas of elevated shear stress, τ(shear), emerge from specific zones of high strain, e(loc), which then spread out as wave fronts, according to the principles of strain localization theory.
A notable shift from spatially extended strain to localized strain was observed as the ratio of the localization length, λ, to the initial system length, L0, increases.

A theoretical framework is established to analyze the shear modulus, G(τ,ω), taking into account its dependence on spatial, temporal, and frequency factors. This framework elucidates the relationship between shear stress and strain waveforms, enabling a detailed examination of the frequency dependence of localized shear stress and strain, denoted as τ(loc)(ω) and e(loc)(ω).

The function τ(loc) exhibits three distinct decay regions, each indicative of critical exponents in scale-free space. As the frequency increases, the relationship follows 1/τ(loc) ∼ ω^{νz}, where ν = 0.5 represents the divergence of the correlation length. Additionally, the parameters α and β, which are influenced by the specifics of the potential's decay, characterize how the critical strain amplitude necessary to trigger strain localization depends on frequency.
The localized energy density, e(loc), shows critical exponents comparable to those of τ(loc), but features distinct critical amplitude exponents, namely α = νz = 1/2 and β = 1/2.

Additionally, the critical exponents and scaling laws were analyzed alongside those of supercooled liquids— for which the model was initially developed—and those of amorphous solids with a distinct potential. This comparison highlighted the alignment between the predictions of the STZ model and the observed phenomena.

These findings indicate that the strain localization theory for amorphous solids, which is based on concepts from supercooled liquid theory, offers a useful framework for comprehending the mechanical behavior of amorphous solids in diverse model systems.

Cognitive radio has garnered significant attention recently because of its ability to autonomously identify unused spectrum for new applications, making it especially valuable in situations where spectrum is scarce.

To prevent disrupting the primary spectrum user, the secondary cognitive radio transmitter must implement rate adaptation to adjust its transmission rate according to the interference experienced by the primary user. However, this interference is often unknown and challenging to monitor.

To address this goal, this paper presents a non-Bayesian rate adaptation strategy that includes two design methods. The first method utilizes a restless multi-armed bandit approach to automatically and adaptively identify the unavailable spectrum. The second method applies Lyapunov optimization to determine the operating point that minimizes the average interference to the primary user.

In particular, the first approach utilizes numerous discrete channel states to simulate the varying and continuous levels of interference. In contrast, the second approach adjusts the transmission rate from a fixed to a dynamic mode based on observed interference, progressively moving towards the operating point that results in the highest average interference.
Simulation results indicate that the proposed methods deliver near-optimal performance regarding effective spectrum utilization and the average interference experienced by the primary user.
The optical and electrical characteristics of diarylethenes (DAs) can be reversibly toggled between two stable states using light of varying wavelengths.

This property has been utilized in the design of optical and photo-switchable molecular devices, encompassing a variety of applications such as photorefractive materials, optical data storage, and other molecular devices.

Recently, molecular devices utilizing diarylethenes have been created, demonstrating photochromism—the capability to alternate between two distinct states, one remaining stable in the dark and the other when exposed to light.
In this research, we provide a theoretical analysis of molecular junctions based on diarylethene.

The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics demonstrate that the DA molecular junctions display reversible and repeatable switching effects when exposed to light of two distinct wavelengths. This suggests that DA molecules have significant potential for use in optical and photo-switchable molecular devices.

The light-driven switching behavior of molecular junctions incorporating photochromic diarylethene derivatives has garnered significant interest recently, thanks to their potential uses in optical memory, photorefractive materials, and optical data storage. This was discussed by Daoyuan Wu, Zhenzhen Qiu, Shaofeng Zhang, Xiangfeng Zhou, and Jingyue Zhang in "Molecular Devices," volume 19, issue 30, pages 12321-23, published in 2020.
So far, numerous diarylethene derivatives have been investigated as foundational components for creating light-driven molecular devices.
Photochromic diarylethene derivatives are typically considered light-driven switching elements, and their corresponding molecular devices are created by incorporating various electrodes.

To investigate the intrinsic switching behaviors of diarylethene derivatives, we designed a novel molecular device in this paper, featuring a diarylethene unit linked to two electrodes via an alkynylene spacer.

The alkynylene spacer exhibits significant flexibility and is capable of undergoing various cis-trans isomerization processes in both light and dark conditions. This ability leads to alterations in the intermolecular forces between diarylethene derivatives, ultimately affecting the electrical properties of the molecular devices.

According to this mechanism, the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics show that the DA molecular junctions demonstrate reversible and repeatable switching effects when exposed to light at two distinct wavelengths. This suggests that DA molecules have promising applications in optical and photo-switchable molecular devices.
In this study, we conduct a theoretical analysis of molecular junctions based on diarylethene compounds.

The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics indicate that the DA molecular junctions demonstrate reversible and cyclable switching effects when illuminated with two different wavelengths of light. This suggests the potential applicability of DA molecules in optical and photo-switchable molecular devices.

A well-recognized challenge in solar physics is the absence of a comprehensive model that accounts for the formation of prominences in the Sun's corona.
Observations reveal that prominences are created by cool, dense plasma that is held in place within the hot, sparse plasma of the solar corona.
Additionally, these filaments are restricted to narrow magnetic field structures that frequently display intricate and non-potential magnetic configurations.

We introduce magnetohydrostatic equilibrium models that inherently generate magnetic fields in alignment with those observed around stable filaments. Additionally, these models effectively accommodate both cool, dense plasma and the hotter coronal plasma, maintaining a state of approximate magnetic equilibrium.
Additionally, the cool, dense plasma, held in place by the magnetic field, encounters only minimal gravitational forces.

As a result, these structures might withstand atmospheric drag and develop into long-lasting features, potentially accounting for the presence of quiescent filaments that can last anywhere from several days to many years.
These structures are also inherently limited to narrow and stable magnetic field configurations.
The solar system comprises four giant planets—Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars—which developed during the later phases of the protoplanetary disk's evolution approximately 4.6 billion years ago.
The planets probably moved from a region beyond the ice line, the boundary beyond which icy materials could not be heated through thermal excitation.
It has been proposed that the migration could have been caused by the forced oscillation of the disk.

As the cores of the planets expanded through core accretion, the eccentricities and inclinations of their orbits increased. This process continued until approximately 200 million years ago, when the outer two planets collided with Mars.
This led to the formation of the present architecture of the gas giants, marked by their eccentric and inclined orbits.
The migration and evolution of the giant planets probably have a significant impact on the current structure of the solar system.
The behavior of the giant planets within the gaseous disk is outlined.
The analytical, two-dimensional hydrodynamic solutions for the Planet-Disk-Planet (PDP) system were introduced.
The movement of the giant planets from outside the ice line was simulated.
The unusual features and tendencies of the current architectures of the giant planets are understood as a consequence of their development within the protoplanetary disk.
The creation of Taylor phase screens is a significant challenge in various applications of linear systems theory and adaptive signal processing.
In this letter, we introduce a technique for synthesizing Taylor phase screens using Karhunen-Loeve (KL) basis functions.
The approach integrates concepts from optimization and compensation.
It involves an optimization problem that is generally non-convex and challenging to solve, but can be effectively approximated using an alternating approach.
The algorithm was tested and confirmed through the synthesis of both polynomial and exponential screens.
The synthesis of Taylor screens presents a greater challenge than that of polynomial screens because it involves creating screens with phases that change rapidly.
The proposed method, however, creates Taylor screens with varying degrees of smoothness while adhering to a natural physical constraint that ensures gradual phase transitions.
Navigating the challenge of balancing multiple objectives is generally a complex task.
This was evident from the observation that the majority of heuristics used for synthesizing Taylor screens tend to converge on a local optimum instead of achieving the global optimum.
In this letter, we showcase our approach to addressing this issue through the application of the KL method.
We introduce a two-step approach for initialization and parameter identification.
We demonstrate that the identified screens meet the physical constraints and exhibit strong approximation capabilities.
We also suggest a multi-start approach that initiates several algorithms for screen synthesis and integrates their outcomes.
We showcase the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm through two design examples and compare its performance with that of leading algorithms in the field.
The source of the light elements lithium, beryllium, and boron in X-ray binaries has been a longstanding question, and the answer remains a topic of ongoing debate.
One can now investigate this issue by detecting and measuring the isotopic ratio of 6Li/7Li in the light elements lithium and beryllium, as it displays distinct behavior in these two contexts.

Specifically, a 6Li/7Li isotopic ratio of less than 10^-11 can only be explained by the light elements originating from outside our galaxy. In contrast, a ratio under 10^-12 suggests that the lithium was produced within stars, including our Sun.

We present new measurements of the 6Li/7Li isotopic ratio in the metal-rich giant Cen X-4, showing a value of 7.3(3) x 10^-12. This ratio aligns with the expectation of lithium formed within the interiors of stars.

We also present the first upper limit for the 6Li/7Li ratio in another metal-rich giant, h Per, which shows a ratio exceeding 10-11. This finding is consistent with the existence of lithium produced in the interiors of stars.
We explore the significance of these findings for the formation processes of lithium in X-ray binaries, as well as potential future research avenues.
This study seeks to examine the internal dynamics of the Indian financial market through the use of high-frequency data.
The analysis focused on the stock prices of the National Stock Exchange (NSE) to identify any indications of positive or negative co-movements.
The analysis utilized two tests derived from finance: the vector error correction model (VECM) and the Granger causality test.

An analysis of the NSE dataset covering the period from January 2009 to June 2017 reveals a significant correlation among various markets across different time lags, with the most pronounced correlations occurring at 2-hour and 4-hour intervals.
These findings contribute to a more profound comprehension of the internal dynamics of the Indian financial market.
The Indian financial market plays a crucial role in significantly contributing to the country's GDP.
It operates as an open economy and serves as a center for foreign exchange transactions.
It boasts high liquidity and provides access to global financial information thanks to its strong international presence.
In addition, India is among the fastest-growing major economies in the world.
The Indian stock markets have experienced significant growth over the last decade, rising from approximately USD 400 billion to around USD 2.5 trillion between 2009 and 2017.
In addition to its significance, the Indian financial market is among the least comprehended.
Similar to the U.S. and other western markets, the Indian market features a highly centralized structure, with a handful of primary stock exchanges exerting considerable influence.
The primary stock exchanges include the BSE (formerly known as the Bombay Stock Exchange), the National Stock Exchange (NSE), and the S&P BSE Sensex index.
Several smaller stock exchanges exist, such as the National Stock Exchange of India, the Indian Stock Exchange, and the Reliance Industries Share Value System.

The Indian financial market has faced criticism for its slow reporting mechanisms and inadequate surveillance, leading to a situation where many transactions go unreported, resulting in limited available information.

A recent temperature study of the brown dwarf 2MASS J05352184-0546085, which is in close orbit with its companion and has become tidally synchronized, reveals a surprisingly low surface temperature of 20.8 ± 0.2 K.
This amount is over 500 K lower than what would have been anticipated based on the detected near-infrared flux.
Unexpectedly, the blackbody emission from J05352184-0546085 cannot account for the observed fluxes by itself.
Alternatively, there could be an additional component at a higher temperature, exhibiting blackbody and Rayleigh-Jeans temperatures of 47.2 ± 1.0 K and 66.5 ± 1.2 K, respectively.
The component at 66.5 K is probably a spiral arm of the Milky Way, and this source might be an unusual Extremely Red Object.

The secondary component might result from an eccentric orbit, where a closer approach in the past—during a time when the system was cooler and brighter—enabled this component to contribute more significantly to the observed fluxes.
As 2MASS J05352184-0546085 draws nearer to its companion, the intensity of this effect will diminish.
A new, highly selective liquid-crystalline chemosensor has been synthesized for detecting sulfur (S).

The chemosensor, designed from an indoline-2-one structure, demonstrates a highly sensitive near-infrared (NIR) fluorescence response for sulfur detection, with a limit of detection (LOD) of 5.3×10−7 M.

The system was capable of distinguishing between S and other frequently encountered anions, except for hydrogen sulfate (H2SO4), where a notable enhancement in NIR fluorescence for S was detected compared to H2SO4.
Fluorescence microscopy imaging of mammalian cells reveals that the chemosensor can cross the cell membrane and effectively detect endogenous sulfide (S2-) within these cells.
Initial, non-targeted live-cell near-infrared fluorescence imaging of mammalian cells treated with the chemosensor shows that the chemosensor can successfully detect S2- within these cells.
These findings suggest that the chemosensor shows significant potential for the sensitive and non-invasive imaging of endogenous S2- within biological systems.
Gamma-ray sources are powerful cosmic emitters of high-energy gamma rays, attracting significant interest from astrophysicists.

TeV J2032+4130, a notable source, was identified by the ground-based Atmospheric Gamma-ray Emitter (AGER) telescope system and the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA), as part of observations conducted by the H.E.S.S., Fermi, and AGILE gamma-ray observatories.
Since its discovery, there has been varying opinion regarding the identity of its source.

Recent findings from the X-Ray Telescope (XRT) on the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory indicate that this source is likely an active galaxy situated 1.3 billion light-years away from Earth, ranking it among the most distant objects ever observed in the universe.
The unexpectedly vast distance and significant luminosity indicate that this source could represent a groundbreaking discovery with tremendous scientific significance.
This study introduces a novel technique using cyclic voltammetry (CV) to characterize phase transitions and predict equilibrium composition.
CV, which stands for cyclic voltammetry, is the primary technique utilized to study electrochemical processes by measuring current as a function of voltage.

In the conventional method for CV measurements, the voltage is gradually raised from an initial value of 0 until it reaches an asymptotic point, indicating that the electrochemical system has completed one full reaction.
This conventional method, recognized for linear cyclic voltammetry (CV), has a number of limitations when it comes to describing electrochemical phase transitions.
In certain instances, a phase change takes place without a full reduction or oxidation of the system.
This partial reduction or oxidation indicates that the system has not achieved an equilibrium state.
The conventional linear CV method does not indicate whether the system has achieved an equilibrium state in terms of its composition.
Another drawback of the linear approach is that it reports only a single voltage value, despite the existence of multiple phases that may have varying voltage levels.

This study introduces a novel method for measuring CV, known as E-C FORC. This approach monitors the voltage trajectory of the system as it transitions through various phases until it achieves equilibrium.
By employing a genetic algorithm, E-C FORC can identify not only the trajectory the system follows during its phase transitions but also the voltage associated with the equilibrium composition.
The method is illustrated using ferricyanide as a representative electrochemical system.
E-C FORC can identify the equilibrium composition of both complex polyphasic systems and those featuring distinct phase transitions.
Furthermore, E-C FORC has the capability to monitor various phase transitions and precisely identify the voltage associated with each one.
This study presents a promising method for characterizing electrochemical phase transitions and forecasting equilibrium composition.
Epsilon Aurigae (ι Aur) is an α2 Canum Venaticorum binary system featuring a primary component that is an F3 IV star and a secondary component that is a K0 IV star.
Epsilon Aurigae is the second-most luminous star in the northern hemisphere and is nearly always visible to the unaided eye.
The main component was encased in a dense envelope filled with hydrogen, which results in it being significantly cooler and less luminous than the Sun.

Consequently, Epsilon Aurigae exhibits a distinctive evolution on the H-R diagram; it remains nearly stationary on the main sequence for an extended period before ultimately transitioning into a giant star many centuries from now.

Historical estimates of the star's distance have fluctuated significantly, ranging from less than 4 parsecs to more than 14 parsecs. However, recent high-precision parallax measurements obtained from the Hipparcos satellite have determined the distance to be 11.65 parsecs.
The IUE spectra of the Epsilon Aurigae system revealed Balmer emission from the primary star, even though the spectrum was primarily influenced by the secondary star.
The IUE data revealed a tenuous, cirrus-like hydrogen envelope surrounding the primary star, with a density at least 20 times lower than that of the star's extended, thicker wind.
The intensity of the emission lines in the spectrum of the primary star fluctuated periodically, following a cycle of 14.4 days, which corresponds to the star's rotation period.

An examination of ultraviolet data collected by the Solar Mass Spectrometer on the Ulysses spacecraft indicated that Epsilon Aurigae was experiencing a mass loss ranging from approximately 10^-9 to 10^-8 kg per second.
This study presents recent UBVJH photometric observations of Epsilon Aurigae.
The discussion includes the changes in temperature of the primary star across different wavelengths, as well as the profiles of the H Lambda emission lines.
The overall brightness of the system is calculated using basic models for both the primary and secondary stars.
Ultimately, the discussion addressed the implications for the primary star's current mass-loss rate and the evolutionary status of the system.
Significant effort has been dedicated to developing surrogate models for black hole (BH) signals in the data analysis of Advanced LIGO (aLIGO).
Although many methods have been developed, Matched Filtering (MF) continues to be the most prevalent technique for detecting BH signals in aLIGO's measurement data.
However, even after being around for decades, the MF technique has never faced scrutiny regarding aBH data.

In this Letter, we apply and evaluate the MF technique using two recently released numerical relativity (NR) black hole merger simulations: the Effective One Body (EOB) model and the Spectral Einstein Code (SpEC) spectral code.
For every simulation, we create the appropriate "template" black hole signal in the frequency domain and process it using a collection of numerical relativity waveforms from GCN catalogs.

Our analysis indicates that in both the low and high frequency ranges, the detection efficiencies of the NR waveforms are significantly lower than 100%, even when dealing with sources that have a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).
In comparison, the MF technique achieves full efficiency in both areas.
We also evaluate the MF technique using simulated Gaussian white noise and demonstrate that the detection efficiencies reach 100% across all signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs).
These findings indicate that NR waveforms are inappropriate for analyzing aLIGO data.
Additionally, the low detection efficiencies of NR waveforms raise questions about aLIGO's assertion that it has detected gravitational waves from the merger of two black holes.
We provide K-band imaging for four regions around four QSOs with redshifts greater than 1.2, as identified in the SDSS Early Data Release.

This is the first instance of deep near-infrared imaging conducted on these sources, and when combined with the existing B- and I-band imagery from the SXDS, it enables the use of color information to explore their morphologies.

The observations support the notion that the candidates serve as host galaxies for absorbed QSOs, based on their optical and near-infrared fluxes and colors, though deep spectroscopy was necessary for confirmation.
The half-light radii of the host galaxies generally exceed 1.5 kpc, which is in line with the measurements of local elliptical galaxies and smaller than those found in most rich galaxy clusters.
This could indicate that the robust absorption systems are situated beyond the clusters and are linked to the more diffuse part of the cluster's dark matter.
For this study, we utilize the ASKER survey data from the NSF, specifically from the SXDS in the SSA13 field.
ASKER is a wide-field survey conducted by IRTF that captured K-band images of 14 candidate clusters identified as X-ray bright in the Chandra Deep Field South (CDF-S).
Alongside the imaging data, we utilize X-ray and spectroscopic data from the CDF-S, in addition to the SDSS galaxy catalog, to conduct a more in-depth examination of these sources.

We analyze the photometry and colors of the host galaxies derived from the imaging data to verify the host status of the four bright QSOs and investigate the morphologies of the host galaxies, which could be influenced by their surrounding environments.

Our observations indicate that the hosts predominantly exhibit normal morphologies, aligning with their classification as elliptical galaxies at z~1.2. Additionally, they have half-light radii of 1.5 kpc, comparable to those found in local rich clusters.
This could suggest that the intense absorption systems are situated beyond the clusters and are linked to the less concentrated component of the cluster's dark matter.

The constraint on the universe's curvature, as determined from the path of light emitted during the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) era, is consistent with a flat universe, with a limit of σ ≤ 10^-5.

Assuming the universe can be accurately modeled using a Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker (FLRW) metric, a value of σ = 0 leads to a constraint on the Hubble parameter, H ≤ 10^-5 (Planck 2013). This is seven orders of magnitude more rigorous than the direct measurement, indicating that the actual limit is likely to be significantly greater than zero.

clean_wm_text: It has been proposed that this substantial discrepancy could signal the emergence of new gravitational physics, such as scalar-tensor theories or potential deviations from General Relativity (GR).

We introduce a straightforward modification of the Friedmann equations that permits a greater deviation of curvature from zero, and we explore the effects of this modification on existing cosmological datasets.
We observe that although this extension loosens the constraint on the Hubble parameter to H ≤ 10^-4, the limit on curvature remains unchanged at σ = 0 with 95% confidence.
We determine that the existing cosmological data does not necessitate a non-zero curvature of the universe at the 95% confidence level.
Spectral efficiency and diversity have historically been opposing needs in wireless networks.
Spectral efficiency pertains to the number of information bits transmitted per second, whereas diversity order assesses the link quality in the presence of fading.

Historically, network coding has demonstrated the ability to enhance spectral efficiency without an increase in diversity order. However, numerous networks necessitate both elevated spectral efficiency and a high diversity order.
This paper demonstrates that network coding combined with multiuser detection (MUD) can achieve high spectral efficiency alongside a substantial diversity order.
We introduce a collaborative transmission protocol that utilizes network coding and multi-user detection (MUD) to simultaneously achieve high spectral efficiency and enhanced diversity.
We examine the protocol through the lens of the degree of freedom (DoF) framework and provide a closed-form approximation for the symmetric scenario.

Our simulations demonstrate that the spectral efficiency and diversity provided by the proposed protocol greatly surpass those of Network Coding with Max-Ratio Combining (MRC) and Network Coding with Successive Interference Cancellation (SIC).
Furthermore, we demonstrate that the protocol is highly effective in optimizing the throughput of non-colluding nodes within a network.

Semi-structured text, such as content derived from the web or engineering documents, consists of implicit schemas, which represent potential relationships among concept words, in addition to explicit tuples that indicate the co-occurrence of these concept words.
In this paper, we introduce a Dynamic User-Defined Similarity Searching (DUSDSS) model that integrates both implicit and explicit relationships to facilitate semi-structured text retrieval.

Using the user-defined semantic space, we create a similarity function to assess the semantic similarity between search terms and retrieve relevant documents, which are ranked according to these similarities.

To accurately capture the semantics of user interests and broaden the scope of the document collection, we propose generating document semantic representations from various perspectives, including topics, authors, and document topic networks.
To effectively assess the relevance between user queries and documents, we introduce a continuous space search strategy that utilizes negative sampling to estimate the ranking metric.
In conclusion, we performed experiments using two public datasets, and the results indicate that our model surpasses the leading methods in both explicit and implicit semantic similarity assessments.
We report the discovery of fifteen new low-mass companions to stars that host planets, utilizing data from the Squeezernigton component of the high-contrast imaging instrument, GPI.
The discovery of these new planets brings the total number of imaged planets to thirty-eight, while the count of stars hosting planets increases to twelve.
The majority of the recent discoveries consist of super-Earth sized planets, which range in diameter from 1.3 to 5.7 times that of Earth and have masses between 2 and 20 times that of Earth.
Two of the planets exhibit extremely high equilibrium temperatures and can be categorized as Hot Neptunes.

Twelve of the newly discovered planets were identified through direct imaging, while fifteen were revealed through high-density Bonner-Powell modeling of the trajectories of planets observed with the GPI.
We have also revised the orbital characteristics for twelve planets, among which eight are likely part of multiple systems.

We also analyze the characteristics of stars that host planets in comparison to similar stars that do not have detected planets. Our findings indicate that stars with planets tend to have higher metallicity and lower spin rates.
Active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are fueled by the accretion of gas and/or stars onto supermassive black holes (SMBHs).

It is thought that the majority of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) located at the centers of typical galaxies have masses under 10^8 solar masses. In contrast, the masses of SMBHs found in active galactic nuclei (AGNs), as inferred from their observed spectra, significantly exceed 10^8 solar masses, and these are referred to as "massive SMBHs" (MSSMHs).
MSSMHs possess greater angular momentum compared to typical SMBHs, and their development necessitates a rapid timescale.
The process by which massive supermassive black holes (MSSMHs) form in the centers of ordinary galaxies remains an unresolved question.
Suzaku conducted the inaugural large-scale survey of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) identified by Swift/BAT in the hard X-ray spectrum (15-50 keV), encompassing a diverse range of black hole masses.
Our analysis revealed that the majority of AGNs identified by Suzaku possess substantial black hole masses and exhibit characteristic featureless spectra, in contrast to NLS1s.

The estimated masses of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) identified by Suzaku exceed 10^9 solar masses, marking them as the most massive SMBHs discovered in the centers of typical galaxies.
We referred to them as "new type" SMBHs (nSMBHs).
We explore the distinctions in the growth patterns of nSMBHs and MSSMHs, as well as the differences in their host galaxies.
In this research, we have discovered mitochondrial colorectal tumor (MCT) peptides that are effective in hindering the proliferation of cancer cells.
MCT1-5 was identified through a functional genomics method.

MCT1-3 are SSL/CBM domains, which represent a structural motif present in various protein families, such as the ubiquitin-like Nedd8, autophagy-related MAP1-LC3, and rRNA-processing Lsg1/Rat8 families.

The antiproliferative MCR peptides interact with the insulin receptor (INSR), obstructing the formation of the insulin-INSR complex. This interference results in the dephosphorylation of RB, hinders the progression of the cell cycle, and ultimately produces an antiproliferative effect.
Cancer cells depend on the phospho-RB pathway for their growth, making MCRs a new category of antiproliferative agents.
Exploring the structures and functions of MCR in greater detail could pave the way for the development of new anticancer medications.
The gene names MCT1, MCT2, and MCT3 correspond to mitochondrial colorectal tumor genes 1, 2, and 3, respectively.
These genes were identified through a functional genomics methodology.

The antiproliferative MCR peptides attach to the insulin receptor (INSR) and prevent the formation of the insulin-INSR complex. This action results in the dephosphorylation of RB, which hinders cell cycle progression and produces an antiproliferative effect.
Cancer cells depend on the phospho-RB pathway for their growth, making MCRs a new class of agents that can inhibit proliferation.
Additional exploration of MCR structures and functions could result in the development of novel anticancer medications.
Insulin and INSR are proteins that play a crucial role in regulating human growth and development.

MCRs, also known as INSR/Ins peptide complexes, can bind to insulin and activate its receptor, which results in decreased INSR tyrosine kinase activity and the inhibition of processes that depend on insulin.
A primary physiological role of insulin is to promote cell proliferation.
MCRs prevent cancer cell proliferation by obstructing the binding of insulin to its receptor.
The insulin-INSR complex consists of two polypeptides of INSR and two molecules of insulin.
The INSR proteins are composed of an extracellular domain, a transmembrane domain, and an intracellular domain that contains the tyrosine kinase domain.

The extracellular domain of the INSR binds to insulin, while the transmembrane domain of INSR conveys the signal across the cell membrane to the intracellular domain. This process triggers the autophosphorylation of the INSR's tyrosine kinase and initiates downstream signaling.
The antiproliferative effect of MCRs may be attributed to the dephosphorylation of RB.
This inhibition resulted from the lack of the insulin-INSR complex and a reduction in INSR tyrosine kinase activity.
In the absence of tyrosine kinase activity, RB loses its phosphate groups and is unable to inhibit cell cycle progression.
The dynamics of vortices in low-dimensional disordered superconductors is a topic of active research.
It is now well understood that at elevated magnetic fields, the behavior of Abrikosov vortices follows the Kibble-Zurek (KZ) theory, meaning it is influenced by the energy spectrum of quasiparticles.

At low magnetic fields, several intriguing experimental phenomena have been observed, including exponential vortex relaxation, aperiodic diffusion, and a deviation from the Kibble-Zurek (KZ) scenario.
All of these phenomena have been interpreted as expressions of the breakdown of vortex quasi-long-range order.
The latter suggests the disruption of the quasiparticle energy spectrum.

In this study, we demonstrate that in superconductors featuring a fractal cluster structure, the dynamics of vortices during the initial phase of resistive transition are influenced by the fractal nature of the cluster arrangement.

We conduct a Monte Carlo simulation using the effective Ginzburg-Landau equation that incorporates the order parameter. Our findings reveal that, during the initial stage of the resistive transition, the correlation function of the order parameter exhibits a power-law behavior characterized by a critical exponent that closely aligns with the value seen in the 2D Ising model in the presence of a magnetic field, particularly when the substrate's dimension matches the fractal dimension of the cluster structure.
